1.verse: These are the messages that came to Isaiah, son of Amoz, in the visions he saw during the reigns of King Uzziah, King Jotham, King Ahaz, and King Hezekiah—all kings of Judah. In these messages God showed him what was going to happen to Judah and Jerusalem in the days ahead.

2.verse: Listen, O heaven and earth, to what the Lord is saying: The children I raised and cared for so long and tenderly have turned against me.

3.verse: Even the animals—the donkey and the ox—know their owner and appreciate his care for them, but not my people Israel. No matter what I do for them, they still don’t care.

4.verse: Oh, what a sinful nation they are! They walk bent-backed beneath their load of guilt. Their fathers before them were evil too. Born to be bad, they have turned their backs upon the Lord and have despised the Holy One of Israel. They have cut themselves off from his help.

5.verse: Oh, my people, haven’t you had enough of punishment? Why will you force me to whip you again and again? Must you forever rebel? From head to foot you are sick and weak and faint, covered with bruises and welts and infected wounds, unanointed and unbound.

6.verse: Oh, my people, haven’t you had enough of punishment? Why will you force me to whip you again and again? Must you forever rebel? From head to foot you are sick and weak and faint, covered with bruises and welts and infected wounds, unanointed and unbound.

7.verse: Your country lies in ruins; your cities are burned; while you watch, foreigners are destroying and plundering everything they see.

8.verse: You stand there helpless and abandoned like a watchman’s shanty in the field when the harvesttime is over—or when the crop is stripped and robbed.

9.verse: If the Lord Almighty had not stepped in to save a few of us, we would have been wiped out as Sodom and Gomorrah were.

10.verse: An apt comparison! Listen, you leaders of Israel, you men of Sodom and Gomorrah, as I call you now. Listen to the Lord. Hear what he is telling you!

11.verse: I am sick of your sacrifices. Don’t bring me any more of them. I don’t want your fat rams; I don’t want to see the blood from your offerings.

12.verse: Who wants your sacrifices when you have no sorrow for your sins? The incense you bring me is a stench in my nostrils. Your holy celebrations of the new moon and the Sabbath, and your special days for fasting—even your most pious meetings—all are frauds! I want nothing more to do with them.

13.verse: Who wants your sacrifices when you have no sorrow for your sins? The incense you bring me is a stench in my nostrils. Your holy celebrations of the new moon and the Sabbath, and your special days for fasting—even your most pious meetings—all are frauds! I want nothing more to do with them.

14.verse: I hate them all; I can’t stand the sight of them.

15.verse: From now on, when you pray with your hands stretched out to heaven, I won’t look or listen. Even though you make many prayers, I will not hear, for your hands are those of murderers; they are covered with the blood of your innocent victims.

16.verse: Oh, wash yourselves! Be clean! Let me no longer see you doing all these wicked things; quit your evil ways.

17.verse: Learn to do good, to be fair, and to help the poor, the fatherless, and widows.

18.verse: Come, let’s talk this over, says the Lord; no matter how deep the stain of your sins, I can take it out and make you as clean as freshly fallen snow. Even if you are stained as red as crimson, I can make you white as wool!

19.verse: If you will only let me help you, if you will only obey, then I will make you rich!

20.verse: But if you keep on turning your backs and refusing to listen to me, you will be killed by your enemies; I, the Lord, have spoken.

21.verse: Jerusalem, once a faithful wife! And now a prostitute! Running after other gods! Once “The City of Fair Play,” but now a gang of murderers.

22.verse: Once like sterling silver; now mixed with worthless alloy! Once so pure, but now diluted like watered-down wine!

23.verse: Your leaders are rebels, companions of thieves; all of them take bribes and won’t defend the widows and orphans.

24.verse: Therefore the Lord, the Mighty One of Israel, says: I will pour out my anger on you, my enemies!

25.verse: I myself will melt you in a smelting pot and skim off your slag.

26.verse: And afterwards I will give you good judges and wise counselors like those you used to have. Then your city shall again be called “The City of Justice” and “The Faithful Town.”

27.verse: Those who return to the Lord, who are just and good, shall be redeemed.

28.verse: (But all sinners shall utterly perish, for they refuse to come to me.)

29.verse: Shame will cover you, and you will blush to think of all those times you sacrificed to idols in your groves of “sacred” oaks.

30.verse: You will perish like a withered tree or a garden without water.

31.verse: The strongest among you will disappear like burning straw; your evil deeds are the spark that sets the straw on fire, and no one will be able to put it out.

1.verse: This is another message to Isaiah from the Lord concerning Judah and Jerusalem:

2.verse: In the last days Jerusalem and the Temple of the Lord will become the world’s greatest attraction, and people from many lands will flow there to worship the Lord.

3.verse: “Come,” everyone will say, “let us go up the mountain of the Lord, to the Temple of the God of Israel; there he will teach us his laws, and we will obey them.” For in those days the world will be ruled from Jerusalem.

4.verse: The Lord will settle international disputes; all the nations will convert their weapons of war into implements of peace. Then at the last all wars will stop and all military training will end.

5.verse: O Israel, come, let us walk in the light of the Lord and be obedient to his laws!

6.verse: The Lord has rejected you because you welcome foreigners from the East who practice magic and communicate with evil spirits, as the Philistines do.

7.verse: Israel has vast treasures of silver and gold, and great numbers of horses and chariots

8.verse: and idols—the land is full of them! They are man-made, and yet you worship them!

9.verse: Small and great, all bow before them; God will not forgive you for this sin.

10.verse: Crawl into the caves in the rocks and hide in terror from his glorious majesty,

11.verse: for the day is coming when your proud looks will be brought low; the Lord alone will be exalted.

12.verse: On that day the Lord Almighty will move against the proud and haughty and bring them to the dust.

13.verse: All the tall cedars of Lebanon and all the mighty oaks of Bashan shall bend low,

14.verse: and all the high mountains and hills,

15.verse: and every high tower and wall,

16.verse: and all the proud ocean ships and trim harbor craft—all shall be crushed before the Lord that day.

17.verse: All the glory of mankind will bow low; the pride of men will lie in the dust, and the Lord alone will be exalted.

18.verse: And all idols will be utterly abolished and destroyed.

19.verse: When the Lord stands up from his throne to shake up the earth, his enemies will crawl with fear into the holes in the rocks and into the caves because of the glory of his majesty.

20.verse: Then at last they will abandon their gold and silver idols to the moles and bats

21.verse: and crawl into the caverns to hide among the jagged rocks at the tops of the cliffs, to try to get away from the terror of the Lord and the glory of his majesty when he rises to terrify the earth.

22.verse: Puny man! Frail as his breath! Don’t ever put your trust in him!

1.verse: The Lord will cut off Jerusalem’s and Judah’s food and water supplies

2.verse: and kill her leaders; he will destroy her armies, judges, prophets, elders,

3.verse: army officers, businessmen, lawyers, magicians, and politicians.

4.verse: Israel’s kings will be like babies, ruling childishly.

5.verse: And the worst sort of anarchy will prevail—everyone stepping on someone else, neighbors fighting neighbors, youths revolting against authority, criminals sneering at honorable men.

6.verse: In those days a man will say to his brother, “You have some extra clothing, so you be our king and take care of this mess.”

7.verse: “No!” he will reply. “I cannot be of any help! I have no extra food or clothes. Don’t get me involved!”

8.verse: Israel’s civil government will be in utter ruin because the Jews have spoken out against their Lord and will not worship him; they offend his glory.

9.verse: The very look on their faces gives them away and shows their guilt. And they boast that their sin is equal to the sin of Sodom; they are not even ashamed. What a catastrophe! They have doomed themselves.

10.verse: But all is well for the godly man. Tell him, “What a reward you are going to get!”

11.verse: But say to the wicked, “Your doom is sure. You too shall get your just deserts. Your well-earned punishment is on the way.”

12.verse: O my people! Can’t you see what fools your rulers are? Weak as women! Foolish as little children playing king. True leaders? No, misleaders! Leading you down the garden path to destruction.

13.verse: The Lord stands up! He is the great Prosecuting Attorney presenting his case against his people!

14.verse: First to feel his wrath will be the elders and the princes, for they have defrauded the poor. They have filled their barns with grain extorted from the helpless peasants.

15.verse: “How dare you grind my people in the dust like that?” the Lord Almighty will demand of them.

16.verse: Next he will judge the haughty Jewish women, who mince along, noses in the air, tinkling bracelets on their ankles, with wanton eyes that rove among the crowds to catch the glances of the men.

17.verse: The Lord will send a plague of scabs to ornament their heads! He will expose their nakedness for all to see.

18.verse: No longer shall they tinkle with self-assurance as they walk. For the Lord will strip away their artful beauty and their ornaments,

19.verse: their necklaces and bracelets and veils of shimmering gauze.

20.verse: Gone shall be their scarves and ankle chains, headbands, earrings, and perfumes;

21.verse: their rings, jewels,

22.verse: party clothes, negligees, capes, ornate combs, and purses;

23.verse: their mirrors, lovely lingerie, beautiful dresses, and veils.

24.verse: Instead of smelling of sweet perfume, they’ll stink; for sashes they’ll use ropes; their well-set hair will all fall out; they’ll wear sacks instead of robes. All their beauty will be gone; all that will be left to them is shame and disgrace.

25.verse: Their husbands shall die in battle; the women, ravaged, shall sit crying on the ground.

26.verse: Their husbands shall die in battle; the women, ravaged, shall sit crying on the ground.

1.verse: At that time so few men will be left alive that seven women will fight over each of them and say, “Let us all marry you! We will furnish our own food and clothing; only let us be called by your name so that we won’t be mocked as old maids.”

2.verse: Those whose names are written down to escape the destruction of Jerusalem will be washed and rinsed of all their moral filth by the horrors and the fire. They will be God’s holy people. And the land will produce for them its lushest bounty and its richest fruit.

3.verse: Those whose names are written down to escape the destruction of Jerusalem will be washed and rinsed of all their moral filth by the horrors and the fire. They will be God’s holy people. And the land will produce for them its lushest bounty and its richest fruit.

4.verse: Those whose names are written down to escape the destruction of Jerusalem will be washed and rinsed of all their moral filth by the horrors and the fire. They will be God’s holy people. And the land will produce for them its lushest bounty and its richest fruit.

5.verse: Then the Lord will provide shade on all Jerusalem—over every home and all its public grounds—a canopy of smoke and cloud throughout the day, and clouds of fire at night, covering the Glorious Land,

6.verse: protecting it from daytime heat and from rains and storms.

1.verse: Now I will sing a song about his vineyard to the one I love. My Beloved has a vineyard on a very fertile hill.

2.verse: He plowed it and took out all the rocks and planted his vineyard with the choicest vines. He built a watchtower and cut a winepress in the rocks. Then he waited for the harvest, but the grapes that grew were wild and sour and not at all the sweet ones he expected.

3.verse: Now, men of Jerusalem and Judah, you have heard the case! You be the judges!

4.verse: What more could I have done? Why did my vineyard give me wild grapes instead of sweet?

5.verse: I will tear down the fences and let my vineyard go to pasture to be trampled by cattle and sheep.

6.verse: I won’t prune it or hoe it, but let it be overgrown with briars and thorns. I will command the clouds not to rain on it anymore.

7.verse: I have given you the story of God’s people. They are the vineyard that I spoke about. Israel and Judah are his pleasant acreage! He expected them to yield a crop of justice, but found bloodshed instead. He expected righteousness, but the cries of deep oppression met his ears.

8.verse: You buy up property so others have no place to live. Your homes are built on great estates so you can be alone in the midst of the earth!

9.verse: But the Lord Almighty has sworn your awful fate—with my own ears I heard him say, “Many a beautiful home will lie deserted, their owners killed or gone.

10.verse: An acre of vineyard will not produce a gallon of juice! Ten bushels of seed will yield a one-bushel crop!”

11.verse: Woe to you who get up early in the morning to go on long drinking bouts that last till late at night—woe to you drunken bums.

12.verse: You furnish lovely music at your grand parties; the orchestras are superb! But for the Lord you have no thought or care.

13.verse: Therefore I will send you into exile far away because you neither know nor care that I have done so much for you. Your great and honored men will starve, and the common people will die of thirst.

14.verse: Hell is licking its chops in anticipation of this delicious morsel, Jerusalem. Her great and small shall be swallowed up, and all her drunken throngs.

15.verse: In that day the haughty shall be brought down to the dust; the proud shall be humbled;

16.verse: but the Lord Almighty is exalted above all, for he alone is holy, just, and good.

17.verse: In those days flocks will feed among the ruins. Lambs and calves and kids will pasture there!

18.verse: Woe to those who drag their sins behind them like a bullock on a rope.

19.verse: They even mock the Holy One of Israel and dare the Lord to punish them. “Hurry up and punish us, O Lord,” they say. “We want to see what you can do!”

20.verse: They say that what is right is wrong and what is wrong is right; that black is white and white is black; bitter is sweet and sweet is bitter.

21.verse: Woe to those who are wise and shrewd in their own eyes!

22.verse: Woe to those who are “heroes” when it comes to drinking and boast about the liquor they can hold.

23.verse: They take bribes to pervert justice, letting the wicked go free and putting innocent men in jail.

24.verse: Therefore God will deal with them and burn them. They will disappear like straw on fire. Their roots will rot and their flowers wither, for they have thrown away the laws of God and despised the word of the Holy One of Israel.

25.verse: That is why the anger of the Lord is hot against his people; that is why he has reached out his hand to smash them. The hills will tremble, and the rotting bodies of his people will be thrown as refuse in the streets. But even so, his anger is not ended; his hand is heavy on them still.

26.verse: He will send a signal to the nations far away, whistling to those at the ends of the earth, and they will come racing toward Jerusalem.

27.verse: They never weary, never stumble, never stop; their belts are tight, their bootstraps strong; they run without stopping for rest or for sleep.

28.verse: Their arrows are sharp; their bows are bent; sparks fly from their horses’ hoofs, and the wheels of their chariots spin like the wind.

29.verse: They roar like lions and pounce upon the prey. They seize my people and carry them off into captivity with none to rescue them.

30.verse: They growl over their victims like the roaring of the sea. Over all Israel lies a pall of darkness and sorrow, and the heavens are black.

1.verse: The year King Uzziah died I saw the Lord! He was sitting on a lofty throne, and the Temple was filled with his glory.

2.verse: Hovering about him were mighty, six-winged angels of fire. With two of their wings they covered their faces, with two others they covered their feet, and with two they flew.

3.verse: In a great antiphonal chorus they sang, “Holy, holy, holy is the Lord Almighty; the whole earth is filled with his glory.”

4.verse: Such singing it was! It shook the Temple to its foundations, and suddenly the entire sanctuary was filled with smoke.

5.verse: Then I said, “My doom is sealed, for I am a foul-mouthed sinner, a member of a sinful, foul-mouthed race; and I have looked upon the King, the Lord of heaven’s armies.”

6.verse: Then one of the mighty angels flew over to the altar and with a pair of tongs picked out a burning coal.

7.verse: He touched my lips with it and said, “Now you are pronounced ‘not guilty’ because this coal has touched your lips. Your sins are all forgiven.”

8.verse: Then I heard the Lord asking, “Whom shall I send as a messenger to my people? Who will go?” And I said, “Lord, I’ll go! Send me.”

9.verse: And he said, “Yes, go. But tell my people this: ‘Though you hear my words repeatedly, you won’t understand them. Though you watch and watch as I perform my miracles, still you won’t know what they mean.’

10.verse: Dull their understanding, close their ears, and shut their eyes. I don’t want them to see or to hear or to understand, or to turn to me to heal them.”

11.verse: Then I said, “Lord, how long will it be before they are ready to listen?” And he replied, “Not until their cities are destroyed—without a person left—and the whole country is an utter wasteland,

12.verse: and they are all taken away as slaves to other countries far away, and all the land of Israel lies deserted!

13.verse: Yet a tenth—a remnant—will survive; and though Israel is invaded again and again and destroyed, yet Israel will be like a tree cut down, whose stump still lives to grow again.”

1.verse: During the reign of Ahaz (the son of Jotham and grandson of Uzziah), Jerusalem was attacked by King Rezin of Syria and King Pekah of Israel (the son of Remaliah). But it was not taken; the city stood.

2.verse: However, when the news came to the royal court, “Syria is allied with Israel against us!” the hearts of the king and his people trembled with fear as the trees of a forest shake in a storm.

3.verse: Then the Lord said to Isaiah, “Go out to meet King Ahaz, you and Shear-jashub, your son. You will find him at the end of the aqueduct that leads from Gihon Spring to the upper reservoir, near the road that leads down to the bleaching field.

4.verse: Tell him to quit worrying. Tell him he needn’t be frightened by the fierce anger of those two has-beens, Rezin and Pekah.

5.verse: Yes, the kings of Syria and Israel are coming against you. “They say,

6.verse: ‘We will invade Judah and throw her people into panic. Then we’ll fight our way into Jerusalem and install the son of Tabeel as their king.’

7.verse: “But the Lord God says: This plan will not succeed,

8.verse: for Damascus will remain the capital of Syria alone, and King Rezin’s kingdom will not increase its boundaries. And within sixty-five years Ephraim, too, will be crushed and broken.

9.verse: Samaria is the capital of Ephraim alone, and King Pekah’s power will not increase. You don’t believe me? If you want me to protect you, you must learn to believe what I say.”

10.verse: Not long after this, the Lord sent this further message to King Ahaz:

11.verse: “Ask me for a sign, Ahaz, to prove that I will indeed crush your enemies as I have said. Ask anything you like, in heaven or on earth.”

12.verse: But the king refused. “No,” he said, “I’ll not bother the Lord with anything like that.”

13.verse: Then Isaiah said: O House of David, you aren’t satisfied to exhaust my patience; you exhaust the Lord’s as well!

14.verse: All right then, the Lord himself will choose the sign—a child shall be born to a virgin! And she shall call him Immanuel (meaning, “God is with us”).

15.verse: By the time this child is weaned and knows right from wrong, the two kings you fear so much—the kings of Israel and Syria*—will both be dead.*

16.verse: By the time this child is weaned and knows right from wrong, the two kings you fear so much—the kings of Israel and Syria*—will both be dead.*

17.verse: But later on, the Lord will bring a terrible curse on you and on your nation and your family. There will be terror such as has not been known since the division of Solomon’s empire into Israel and Judah—the mighty king of Assyria will come with his great army!

18.verse: At that time the Lord will whistle for the army of Upper Egypt, and of Assyria too, to swarm down upon you like flies and destroy you, like bees to sting and to kill.

19.verse: They will come in vast hordes, spreading across the whole land, even into the desolate valleys, caves, and thorny parts, as well as to all your fertile acres.

20.verse: In that day the Lord will take this “razor”—these Assyrians you have hired to save you—and use it on you to shave off everything you have: your land, your crops, your people.*

21.verse: When they finally stop plundering, the whole nation will be a pastureland; whole flocks and herds will be destroyed, and a farmer will be fortunate to have a cow and two sheep left. But the abundant pastureland will yield plenty of milk, and everyone left will live on curds and wild honey.

22.verse: When they finally stop plundering, the whole nation will be a pastureland; whole flocks and herds will be destroyed, and a farmer will be fortunate to have a cow and two sheep left. But the abundant pastureland will yield plenty of milk, and everyone left will live on curds and wild honey.

23.verse: At that time the lush vineyards will become patches of briars.

24.verse: All the land will be one vast thornfield, a hunting ground overrun by wildlife.

25.verse: No one will go to the fertile hillsides where once the gardens grew, for thorns will cover them; cattle, sheep, and goats will graze there.

1.verse: Again the Lord sent me a message: “Make a large signboard and write on it the birth announcement of the son I am going to give you. Use capital letters! His name will be Maher-shalal-hash-baz, which means ‘Your enemies will soon be destroyed.’”

2.verse: I asked Uriah the priest and Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah, both known as honest men, to watch me as I wrote so they could testify that I had written it before the child was even on the way.

3.verse: Then I had sexual intercourse with my wife and she conceived and bore me a son. And the Lord said, “Call him Maher-shalal-hash-baz.

4.verse: This name prophesies that within a couple of years, before this child is even old enough to say ‘Daddy’ or ‘Mommy,’ the king of Assyria will invade both Damascus and Samaria and carry away their riches.”

5.verse: Then the Lord spoke to me again and said:

6.verse: “Since the people of Jerusalem are planning to refuse my gentle care and are enthusiastic about asking King Rezin and King Pekah to come and aid them,

7.verse: therefore I will overwhelm my people with Euphrates’ mighty flood; the king of Assyria and all his mighty armies will rage against them. This flood will overflow all its channels and sweep into your land of Judah, O Immanuel, submerging it from end to end.”

8.verse: therefore I will overwhelm my people with Euphrates’ mighty flood; the king of Assyria and all his mighty armies will rage against them. This flood will overflow all its channels and sweep into your land of Judah, O Immanuel, submerging it from end to end.”

9.verse: Do your worst, O Syria and Israel, our enemies,* but you will not succeed—you will be shattered. Listen to me, all you enemies of ours: Prepare for war against us—and perish! Yes! Perish! Call your councils of war, develop your strategies, prepare your plans of attacking us, and perish! For God is with us.*

10.verse: Do your worst, O Syria and Israel, our enemies,* but you will not succeed—you will be shattered. Listen to me, all you enemies of ours: Prepare for war against us—and perish! Yes! Perish! Call your councils of war, develop your strategies, prepare your plans of attacking us, and perish! For God is with us.*

11.verse: The Lord has said in strongest terms: Do not under any circumstances go along with the plans of Judah to surrender to Syria and Israel.

12.verse: Don’t let people call you a traitor for staying true to God. Don’t you panic as so many of your neighbors are doing when they think of Syria and Israel attacking you.

13.verse: Don’t fear anything except the Lord of the armies of heaven! If you fear him, you need fear nothing else.

14.verse: He will be your safety; but Israel and Judah have refused his care and thereby stumbled against the Rock of their salvation and lie fallen and crushed beneath it: God’s presence among them has endangered them!

15.verse: He will be your safety; but Israel and Judah have refused his care and thereby stumbled against the Rock of their salvation and lie fallen and crushed beneath it: God’s presence among them has endangered them!

16.verse: Write down all these things I am going to do, says the Lord, and seal them up for the future. Entrust them to some godly man to pass on down to godly men of future generations.

17.verse: I will wait for the Lord to help us, though he is hiding now. My only hope is in him.

18.verse: I and the children God has given me have symbolic names that reveal the plans of the Lord of heaven’s armies for his people: Isaiah means “Jehovah will save (his people),” Shear-jashub means “A remnant shall return,” and Maher-shalal-hash-baz means “Your enemies will soon be destroyed.”

19.verse: So why are you trying to find out the future by consulting witches and mediums? Don’t listen to their whisperings and mutterings. Can the living find out the future from the dead? Why not ask your God?

20.verse: “Check these witches’ words against the Word of God!” he says. “If their messages are different than mine, it is because I have not sent them; for they have no light or truth in them.

21.verse: My people will be led away captive, stumbling, weary and hungry. And because they are hungry, they will rave and shake their fists at heaven and curse their King and their God.

22.verse: Wherever they look there will be trouble and anguish and dark despair. And they will be thrust out into the darkness.”

1.verse: Nevertheless, that time of darkness and despair shall not go on forever. Though soon the land of Zebulun and Naphtali will be under God’s contempt and judgment, yet in the future these very lands, Galilee and northern Transjordan, where lies the road to the sea, will be filled with glory.

2.verse: The people who walk in darkness shall see a great Light—a Light that will shine on all those who live in the land of the shadow of death.

3.verse: For Israel will again be great, filled with joy like that of reapers when the harvesttime has come, and like that of men dividing up the plunder they have won.

4.verse: For God will break the chains that bind his people and the whip that scourges them, just as he did when he destroyed the vast host of the Midianites by Gideon’s little band.

5.verse: In that glorious day of peace there will no longer be the issuing of battle gear; no more the bloodstained uniforms of war; all such will be burned.

6.verse: For unto us a child is born; unto us a son is given; and the government shall be upon his shoulder. These will be his royal titles: “Wonderful,” “Counselor,” “The Mighty God,” “The Everlasting Father,” “The Prince of Peace.”

7.verse: His ever-expanding, peaceful government will never end. He will rule with perfect fairness and justice from the throne of his father David. He will bring true justice and peace to all the nations of the world. This is going to happen because the Lord of heaven’s armies has dedicated himself to do it!

8.verse: The Lord has spoken out against that braggart Israel who says that though our land lies in ruins now, we will rebuild it better than before. The sycamore trees are cut down, but we will replace them with cedars!

9.verse: The Lord has spoken out against that braggart Israel who says that though our land lies in ruins now, we will rebuild it better than before. The sycamore trees are cut down, but we will replace them with cedars!

10.verse: The Lord has spoken out against that braggart Israel who says that though our land lies in ruins now, we will rebuild it better than before. The sycamore trees are cut down, but we will replace them with cedars!

11.verse: The Lord’s reply to your bragging is to bring your enemies against you—the Syrians on the east and the Philistines on the west. With bared fangs they will devour Israel. And even then the Lord’s anger against you will not be satisfied—his fist will still be poised to smash you.

12.verse: The Lord’s reply to your bragging is to bring your enemies against you—the Syrians on the east and the Philistines on the west. With bared fangs they will devour Israel. And even then the Lord’s anger against you will not be satisfied—his fist will still be poised to smash you.

13.verse: For after all this punishment you will not repent and turn to him, the Lord of heaven’s armies.

14.verse: Therefore the Lord, in one day, will destroy the leaders of Israel and the lying prophets.

15.verse: Therefore the Lord, in one day, will destroy the leaders of Israel and the lying prophets.

16.verse: For the leaders of his people have led them down the paths of ruin.

17.verse: That is why the Lord has no joy in their young men and no mercy upon even the widows and orphans, for they are all filthy-mouthed, wicked liars. That is why his anger is not yet satisfied, but his fist is still poised to smash them all.

18.verse: He will burn up all this wickedness, these thorns and briars; and the flames will consume the forests too, and send a vast cloud of smoke billowing up from their burning.

19.verse: The land is blackened by that fire, by the wrath of the Lord of heaven’s armies. The people are fuel for the fire. Each fights against his brother to steal his food but will never have enough. Finally they will even eat their own children!

20.verse: The land is blackened by that fire, by the wrath of the Lord of heaven’s armies. The people are fuel for the fire. Each fights against his brother to steal his food but will never have enough. Finally they will even eat their own children!

21.verse: Manasseh against Ephraim and Ephraim against Manasseh—and both against Judah. Yet even after all of this, God’s anger is not yet satisfied. His hand is still heavy upon them to crush them.

1.verse: Woe to unjust judges and to those who issue unfair laws, says the Lord,

2.verse: so that there is no justice for the poor, the widows, and orphans. Yes, it is true that they even rob the widows and fatherless children.

3.verse: Oh, what will you do when I visit you in that day when I send desolation upon you from a distant land? To whom will you turn then for your help? Where will your treasures be safe?

4.verse: I will not help you; you will stumble along as prisoners or lie among the slain. And even then my anger will not be satisfied, but my fist will still be poised to strike you.

5.verse: Assyria is the whip of my anger; his military strength is my weapon upon this godless nation, doomed and damned; he will enslave them and plunder them and trample them like dirt beneath his feet.

6.verse: Assyria is the whip of my anger; his military strength is my weapon upon this godless nation, doomed and damned; he will enslave them and plunder them and trample them like dirt beneath his feet.

7.verse: But the king of Assyria will not know that it is I who sent him. He will merely think he is attacking my people as part of his plan to conquer the world.

8.verse: He will declare that every one of his princes will soon be a king, ruling a conquered land.

9.verse: “We will destroy Calno just as we did Carchemish,” he will say, “and Hamath will go down before us as Arpad did; and we will destroy Samaria just as we did Damascus.

10.verse: Yes, we have finished off many a kingdom whose idols were far greater than those in Jerusalem and Samaria,

11.verse: so when we have defeated Samaria and her idols, we will destroy Jerusalem with hers.”

12.verse: After the Lord has used the king of Assyria to accomplish his purpose, then he will turn upon the Assyrians and punish them too—for they are proud and haughty men.

13.verse: They boast, “We in our own power and wisdom have won these wars. We are great and wise. By our own strength we broke down the walls and destroyed the people and carried off their treasures.

14.verse: In our greatness we have robbed their nests of riches and gathered up kingdoms as a farmer gathers eggs, and no one can move a finger or open his mouth to peep against us!”

15.verse: But the Lord says, “Shall the ax boast greater power than the man who uses it? Is the saw greater than the man who saws? Can a rod strike unless a hand is moving it? Can a cane walk by itself?”

16.verse: Because of all your evil boasting, O king of Assyria, the Lord of Hosts will send a plague among your proud troops and strike them down.

17.verse: God, the Light and Holy One of Israel, will be the fire and flame that will destroy them. In a single night he will burn those thorns and briars, the Assyrians who destroyed the land of Israel.

18.verse: Assyria’s vast army is like a glorious forest, yet it will be destroyed. The Lord will destroy them, soul and body, as when a sick man wastes away.

19.verse: Only a few from all that mighty army will be left; so few a child could count them!

20.verse: Then at last those left in Israel and in Judah will trust the Lord, the Holy One of Israel, instead of fearing the Assyrians.

21.verse: A remnant of them will return to the mighty God.

22.verse: But though Israel be now as many as the sands along the shore, yet only a few of them will be left to return at that time; God has rightly decided to destroy his people.

23.verse: Yes, it has already been decided by the Lord God to consume them.

24.verse: Therefore the Lord God says, “O my people in Jerusalem, don’t be afraid of the Assyrians when they oppress you just as the Egyptians did long ago.

25.verse: It will not last very long; in a little while my anger against you will end, and then it will rise against them to destroy them.”

26.verse: The Lord Almighty will send his angel to slay them in a mighty slaughter like the time when Gideon triumphed over Midian at the rock of Oreb or the time God drowned the Egyptian armies in the sea.

27.verse: On that day God will end the bondage of his people. He will break the yoke of slavery off their necks and destroy it as decreed.

28.verse: Look, the mighty armies of Assyria are coming! Now they are at Aiath, now at Migron; they are storing some of their equipment at Michmash and crossing over the pass; they are staying overnight at Geba. Fear strikes the city of Ramah; all the people of Gibeah—the city of Saul—are running for their lives.

29.verse: Look, the mighty armies of Assyria are coming! Now they are at Aiath, now at Migron; they are storing some of their equipment at Michmash and crossing over the pass; they are staying overnight at Geba. Fear strikes the city of Ramah; all the people of Gibeah—the city of Saul—are running for their lives.

30.verse: Well may you scream in terror, O people of Gallim. Shout out a warning to Laish, for the mighty army comes. O poor Anathoth, what a fate is yours!

31.verse: There go the people of Madmenah, all fleeing, and the citizens of Gebim are preparing to run.

32.verse: But the enemy stops at Nob for the remainder of that day. He shakes his fist at Jerusalem on Mount Zion.

33.verse: Then, look, look! The Lord, the Lord of the armies of heaven, is chopping down the mighty tree! He is destroying all of that vast army, great and small alike, both officers and men.

34.verse: He, the Mighty One, will cut down the enemy as a woodsman’s ax cuts down the forest trees in Lebanon.

1.verse: The royal line of David will be cut off, chopped down like a tree; but from the stump will grow a Shoot—yes, a new Branch* from the old root.

2.verse: And the Spirit of the Lord shall rest upon him, the Spirit of wisdom, understanding, counsel, and might; the Spirit of knowledge and of the fear of the Lord.

3.verse: His delight will be obedience to the Lord. He will not judge by appearance, false evidence, or hearsay,

4.verse: but will defend the poor and the exploited. He will rule against the wicked who oppress them.

5.verse: For he will be clothed with fairness and with truth.

6.verse: In that day the wolf and the lamb will lie down together, and the leopard and goats will be at peace. Calves and fat cattle will be safe among lions, and a little child shall lead them all.

7.verse: The cows will graze among bears; cubs and calves will lie down together, and lions will eat grass like the cows.

8.verse: Babies will crawl safely among poisonous snakes, and a little child who puts his hand in a nest of deadly adders will pull it out unharmed.

9.verse: Nothing will hurt or destroy in all my holy mountain, for as the waters fill the sea, so shall the earth be full of the knowledge of the Lord.

10.verse: In that day he who created the royal dynasty of David will be a banner of salvation to all the world. The nations will rally to him, for the land where he lives will be a glorious place.

11.verse: At that time the Lord will bring back a remnant of his people for the second time, returning them to the land of Israel from Assyria, Upper and Lower Egypt, Ethiopia, Elam, Babylonia, Hamath, and all the distant coastal lands.

12.verse: He will raise a flag among the nations for them to rally to; he will gather the scattered Israelites from the ends of the earth.

13.verse: Then at last the jealousy between Israel and Judah will end; they will not fight each other anymore.

14.verse: Together they will fly against the nations possessing their land on the east and on the west, uniting forces to destroy them, and they will occupy the nations of Edom and Moab and Ammon.

15.verse: The Lord will dry a path through the Red Sea and wave his hand over the Euphrates,* sending a mighty wind to divide it into seven streams that can easily be crossed.

16.verse: He will make a highway from Assyria for the remnant there, just as he did for all of Israel long ago when they returned from Egypt.

1.verse: On that day you will say, “Praise the Lord! He was angry with me, but now he comforts me.

2.verse: See, God has come to save me! I will trust and not be afraid, for the Lord is my strength and song; he is my salvation.

3.verse: Oh, the joy of drinking deeply from the Fountain of Salvation!”

4.verse: In that wonderful day you will say, “Thank the Lord! Praise his name! Tell the world about his wondrous love. How mighty he is!”

5.verse: Sing to the Lord, for he has done wonderful things. Make known his praise around the world.

6.verse: Let all the people of Jerusalem shout his praise with joy. For great and mighty is the Holy One of Israel, who lives among you.

1.verse: This is the vision God showed Isaiah (son of Amoz) concerning Babylon’s doom.

2.verse: See the flags waving as their enemy attacks. Shout to them, O Israel, and wave them on as they march against Babylon to destroy the palaces of the rich and mighty.

3.verse: I, the Lord, have set apart these armies for this task; I have called those rejoicing in their strength to do this work, to satisfy my anger.

4.verse: Hear the tumult on the mountains! Listen as the armies march! It is the tumult and the shout of many nations. The Lord Almighty has brought them here,

5.verse: from countries far away. They are his weapons against you, O Babylon. They carry his anger with them and will destroy your whole land.

6.verse: Scream in terror, for the Lord’s time has come, the time for the Almighty to crush you.

7.verse: Your arms lie paralyzed with fear; the strongest hearts melt

8.verse: and are afraid. Fear grips you with terrible pangs, like those of a woman in labor. You look at one another, helpless, as the flames of the burning city reflect upon your pallid faces.

9.verse: For see, the day of the Lord is coming, the terrible day of his wrath and fierce anger. The land shall be destroyed and all the sinners with it.

10.verse: The heavens will be black above them. No light will shine from stars or sun or moon.

11.verse: And I will punish the world for its evil, the wicked for their sin; I will crush the arrogance of the proud man and the haughtiness of the rich.

12.verse: Few will live when I have finished up my work. Men will be as scarce as gold—of greater value than the gold of Ophir.

13.verse: For I will shake the heavens in my wrath and fierce anger, and the earth will move from its place in the skies.

14.verse: The armies of Babylon will run until exhausted, fleeing back to their own land like deer chased by dogs, wandering like sheep deserted by their shepherd.

15.verse: Those who don’t run will be butchered.

16.verse: Their little children will be dashed to death against the pavement right before their eyes; their homes will be sacked and their wives raped by the attacking hordes.

17.verse: For I will stir up the Medes against Babylon, and no amount of silver or gold will buy them off.

18.verse: The attacking armies will have no mercy on the young people of Babylon or the babies or the children.

19.verse: And so Babylon, the most glorious of kingdoms, the flower of Chaldean culture, will be as utterly destroyed as Sodom and Gomorrah were when God sent fire from heaven;

20.verse: Babylon will never rise again. Generation after generation will come and go, but the land will never again be lived in. The nomads will not even camp there. The shepherds won’t let their sheep stay overnight.

21.verse: The wild animals of the desert will make it their home. The houses will be haunted by howling creatures. Ostriches will live there, and the demons will come there to dance.

22.verse: Hyenas and jackals will den within the palaces. Babylon’s days are numbered; her time of doom will soon be here.

1.verse: But the Lord will have mercy on the Israelis; they are still his special ones. He will bring them back to settle once again in the land of Israel. And many nationalities will come and join them there and be their loyal allies.

2.verse: The nations of the world will help them to return, and those coming to live in their land will serve them. Those enslaving Israel will be enslaved—Israel shall rule her enemies!

3.verse: In that wonderful day when the Lord gives his people rest from sorrow and fear, from slavery and chains,

4.verse: you will jeer at the king of Babylon and say, “You bully, you! At last you have what was coming to you!

5.verse: For the Lord has crushed your wicked power and broken your evil rule.”

6.verse: You persecuted my people with unceasing blows of rage and held the nations in your angry grip. You were unrestrained in tyranny.

7.verse: But at last the whole earth is at rest and is quiet! All the world begins to sing!

8.verse: Even the trees of the woods—the fir trees and cedars of Lebanon—sing out this joyous song: “Your power is broken; no one will bother us now; at last we have peace.”

9.verse: The denizens of hell crowd to meet you as you enter their domain. World leaders and earth’s mightiest kings, long dead, are there to see you.

10.verse: With one voice they all cry out, “Now you are as weak as we are!”

11.verse: Your might and power are gone; they are buried with you. All the pleasant music in your palace has ceased; now maggots are your sheet, worms your blanket!

12.verse: How you are fallen from heaven, O Lucifer, son of the morning! How you are cut down to the ground—mighty though you were against the nations of the world.

13.verse: For you said to yourself, “I will ascend to heaven and rule the angels. I will take the highest throne. I will preside on the Mount of Assembly far away in the north.*

14.verse: I will climb to the highest heavens and be like the Most High.”

15.verse: But instead, you will be brought down to the pit of hell, down to its lowest depths.

16.verse: Everyone there will stare at you and ask, “Can this be the one who shook the earth and the kingdoms of the world?

17.verse: Can this be the one who destroyed the world and made it into a shambles, who demolished its greatest cities and had no mercy on his prisoners?”

18.verse: The kings of the nations lie in stately glory in their graves,

19.verse: but your body is thrown out like a broken branch; it lies in an open grave, covered with the dead bodies of those slain in battle. It lies as a carcass in the road, trampled and mangled by horses’ hoofs.

20.verse: No monument will be given you, for you have destroyed your nation and slain your people. Your son will not succeed you as the king.

21.verse: Slay the children of this sinner. Do not let them rise and conquer the land nor rebuild the cities of the world.

22.verse: I, myself, have risen against him, says the Lord of heaven’s armies, and will cut off his children and his children’s children from ever sitting on his throne.

23.verse: I will make Babylon into a desolate land of porcupines, full of swamps and marshes. I will sweep the land with the broom of destruction, says the Lord of the armies of heaven.

24.verse: He has taken an oath to do it! For this is his purpose and plan.

25.verse: I have decided to break the Assyrian army when they are in Israel and to crush them on my mountains; my people shall no longer be their slaves.

26.verse: This is my plan for the whole earth—I will do it by my mighty power that reaches everywhere around the world.

27.verse: The Lord, the God of battle, has spoken—who can change his plans? When his hand moves, who can stop him?

28.verse: This is the message that came to me the year King Ahaz died:

29.verse: Don’t rejoice, Philistines, that the king who smote you is dead. That rod is broken, yes; but his son will be a greater scourge to you than his father ever was! From the snake will be born an adder, a fiery serpent to destroy you!

30.verse: I will shepherd the poor of my people; they shall graze in my pasture! The needy shall lie down in peace. But as for you—I will wipe you out with famine and the sword.

31.verse: Weep, Philistine cities—you are doomed. All your nation is doomed. For a perfectly trained army is coming down from the north against you.

32.verse: What then shall we tell the reporters? Tell them that the Lord has founded Jerusalem and is determined that the poor of his people will find a refuge within her walls.

1.verse: Here is God’s message to Moab: In one night your cities of Ar and Kir will be destroyed.

2.verse: Your people in Dibon go mourning to their temples to weep for the fate of Nebo and Medeba; they shave their heads in sorrow and cut off their beards.

3.verse: They wear sackcloth through the streets, and from every home comes the sound of weeping.

4.verse: The cries from the cities of Heshbon and Elealeh are heard far away, even in Jahaz. The bravest warriors of Moab cry in utter terror.

5.verse: My heart weeps for Moab! His people flee to Zoar and Eglath. Weeping, they climb the upward road to Luhith, and their crying will be heard all along the road to Horonaim.

6.verse: Even Nimrim River is desolate! The grassy banks are dried up and the tender plants are gone.

7.verse: The desperate refugees take only the possessions they can carry and flee across the Brook of Willows.

8.verse: The whole land of Moab is a land of weeping from one end to the other.

9.verse: The stream near Dibon will run red with blood, but I am not through with Dibon yet! Lions will hunt down the survivors, both those who escape and those who remain.

1.verse: Moab’s refugees at Sela send lambs as a token of alliance with the king of Judah.

2.verse: The women of Moab are left at the fords of the Arnon River like homeless birds.

3.verse: The ambassadors, who accompany the gift to Jerusalem plead for advice and help. “Give us sanctuary. Protect us. Do not turn us over to our foes.

4.verse: Let our outcasts stay among you; hide them from our enemies! God will reward you for your kindness to us. If you let Moab’s fugitives settle among you, then when the terror is past, God will establish David’s throne forever, and on that throne he will place a just and righteous King.”

5.verse: Let our outcasts stay among you; hide them from our enemies! God will reward you for your kindness to us. If you let Moab’s fugitives settle among you, then when the terror is past, God will establish David’s throne forever, and on that throne he will place a just and righteous King.”

6.verse: Is this proud Moab, concerning which we heard so much? His arrogance and insolence are all gone now!

7.verse: Therefore all Moab weeps. Yes, Moab, you will mourn for stricken Kir-hareseth,

8.verse: and for the abandoned farms of Heshbon and the vineyards at Sibmah. The enemy warlords have cut down the best of the grapevines; their armies spread out as far as Jazer in the deserts, and even down to the sea.

9.verse: So I wail and lament for Jazer and the vineyards of Sibmah. My tears shall flow for Heshbon and Elealeh, for destruction has come upon their summer fruits and harvests.

10.verse: Gone now is the gladness, gone the joy of harvest. The happy singing in the vineyards will be heard no more; the treading out of the grapes in the winepresses has ceased forever. I have ended all their harvest joys.

11.verse: I will weep, weep, weep, for Moab; and my sorrow for Kir-hareseth will be very great.

12.verse: The people of Moab will pray in anguish to their idols at the tops of the hills, but it will do no good; they will cry to their gods in their idol temples, but none will come to save them.

13.verse: All this concerning Moab has been said before; but now the Lord says that within three years, without fail, the glory of Moab shall be ended, and few of all its people will be left alive.

14.verse: All this concerning Moab has been said before; but now the Lord says that within three years, without fail, the glory of Moab shall be ended, and few of all its people will be left alive.

1.verse: This is God’s message to Damascus, capital of Syria: Look, Damascus is gone! It is no longer a city—it has become a heap of ruins!

2.verse: The cities of Aroer are deserted. Sheep pasture there, lying quiet and unafraid, with no one to chase them away.

3.verse: The strength of Israel and the power of Damascus will end, and the remnant of Syria shall be destroyed. For as Israel’s glory departed, so theirs, too, will disappear, declares the Lord Almighty.

4.verse: Yes, the glory of Israel will be very dim when poverty stalks the land.

5.verse: Israel will be as abandoned as the harvested grain fields in the valley of Rephaim.

6.verse: Oh, a very few of her people will be left, just as a few stray olives are left on the trees when the harvest is ended, two or three in the highest branches, four or five out on the tips of the limbs. That is how it will be in Damascus and Israel—stripped bare of people except for a few of the poor who remain.

7.verse: Then at last they will think of God their Creator and have respect for the Holy One of Israel.

8.verse: They will no longer ask their idols for help in that day, neither will they worship what their hands have made! They will no longer have respect for the images of Ashtaroth and the sun idols.

9.verse: Their largest cities will be as deserted as the distant wooded hills and mountaintops and become like the abandoned cities of the Amorites, deserted when the Israelites approached (so long ago).

10.verse: Why? Because you have turned from the God who can save you—the Rock who can hide you; therefore, even though you plant a wonderful, rare crop of greatest value,

11.verse: and though it grows so well that it will blossom on the very morning that you plant it, yet you will never harvest it—your only harvest will be a pile of grief and incurable pain.

12.verse: Look, see the armies thundering toward God’s land.

13.verse: But though they roar like breakers rolling upon a beach, God will silence them. They will flee, scattered like chaff by the wind, like whirling dust before a storm.

14.verse: In the evening Israel waits in terror, but by dawn her enemies are dead. This is the just reward of those who plunder and destroy the people of God.

1.verse: Ah, land beyond the upper reaches of the Nile, where winged sailboats glide along the river!

2.verse: Land that sends ambassadors in fast boats down the Nile! Let swift messengers return to you, O strong and supple nation feared far and wide, a conquering, destroying nation whose land the upper Nile divides. And this is the message sent to you:

3.verse: When I raise my battle flag upon the mountain, let all the world take notice! When I blow the trumpet, listen!

4.verse: For the Lord has told me this: Let your mighty army now advance against the land of Israel. God will watch quietly from his Temple in Jerusalem—serene as on a pleasant summer day or a lovely autumn morning during harvesttime.

5.verse: But before you have begun the attack, and while your plans are ripening like grapes, he will cut you off as though with pruning shears. He will snip the spreading tendrils.

6.verse: Your mighty army will be left dead on the field for the mountain birds and wild animals to eat; the vultures will tear bodies all summer, and the wild animals will gnaw bones all winter.

7.verse: But the time will come when that strong and mighty nation, a terror to all both far and near, that conquering, destroying nation whose land the rivers divide, will bring gifts to the Lord Almighty in Jerusalem, where he has placed his name.

1.verse: This is God’s message concerning Egypt: Look, the Lord is coming against Egypt, riding on a swift cloud; the idols of Egypt tremble; the hearts of the Egyptians melt with fear.

2.verse: I will set them to fighting against each other—brother against brother, neighbor against neighbor, city against city, province against province.

3.verse: Her wise counselors are all at their wits’ end to know what to do; they plead with their idols for wisdom and call upon mediums, wizards, and witches to show them what to do.

4.verse: I will hand over Egypt to a hard, cruel master, to a vicious king, says the Lord Almighty.

5.verse: And the waters of the Nile will fail to rise and flood the fields; the ditches will be parched and dry,

6.verse: their channels fouled with rotting reeds.

7.verse: All green things along the riverbank will wither and blow away. All crops will perish; everything will die.

8.verse: The fishermen will weep for lack of work; those who fish with hooks and those who use the nets will all be unemployed.

9.verse: The weavers will have no flax or cotton, for the crops will fail.

10.verse: Great men and small—all will be crushed and broken.

11.verse: What fools the counselors of Zoan are! Their best counsel to the king of Egypt is utterly stupid and wrong. Will they still boast of their wisdom? Will they dare tell Pharaoh about the long line of wise men they have come from?

12.verse: What has happened to your “wise counselors,” O Pharaoh? Where has their wisdom gone? If they are wise, let them tell you what the Lord is going to do to Egypt.

13.verse: The “wise men” from Zoan are also fools, and those from Memphis are utterly deluded. They are the best you can find, but they have ruined Egypt with their foolish counsel.

14.verse: The Lord has sent a spirit of foolishness on them, so that all their suggestions are wrong; they make Egypt stagger like a sick drunkard.

15.verse: Egypt cannot be saved by anything or anybody—no one can show her the way.

16.verse: In that day the Egyptians will be as weak as women, cowering in fear beneath the upraised fist of God.

17.verse: Just to speak the name of Israel will strike deep terror in their hearts, for the Lord Almighty has laid his plans against them.

18.verse: At that time five of the cities of Egypt will follow the Lord Almighty and will begin to speak the Hebrew language. One of these will be Heliopolis, “The City of the Sun.”

19.verse: And there will be an altar to the Lord in the heart of Egypt in those days and a monument to the Lord at its border.

20.verse: This will be for a sign of loyalty to the Lord Almighty; then when they cry to the Lord for help against those who oppress them, he will send them a savior—and he shall deliver them.

21.verse: In that day the Lord will make himself known to the Egyptians. Yes, they will know the Lord and give their sacrifices and offerings to him; they will make promises to God and keep them.

22.verse: The Lord will smite Egypt and then restore her! For the Egyptians will turn to the Lord and he will listen to their plea and heal them.

23.verse: In that day Egypt and Iraq will be connected by a highway, and the Egyptians and the Iraqis will move freely back and forth between their lands, and they shall worship the same God.

24.verse: And Israel will be their ally; the three will be together, and Israel will be a blessing to them.

25.verse: For the Lord will bless Egypt and Iraq because of their friendship with Israel. He will say, “Blessed be Egypt, my people; blessed be Iraq, the land I have made; blessed be Israel, my inheritance!”

1.verse: In the year when Sargon, king of Assyria, sent the commander-in-chief of his army against the Philistine city of Ashdod and captured it,

2.verse: the Lord told Isaiah, the son of Amoz, to take off his clothing, including his shoes, and to walk around naked and barefoot. And Isaiah did as he was told.

3.verse: Then the Lord said, My servant Isaiah, who has been walking naked and barefoot for the last three years, is a symbol of the terrible troubles I will bring upon Egypt and Ethiopia.

4.verse: For the king of Assyria will take away the Egyptians and Ethiopians as prisoners, making them walk naked and barefoot, both young and old, their buttocks uncovered, to the shame of Egypt.

5.verse: Then how dismayed the Philistines will be, who counted on “Ethiopia’s power” and their “glorious ally,” Egypt! And they will say, “If this can happen to Egypt, what chance have we?”

6.verse: Then how dismayed the Philistines will be, who counted on “Ethiopia’s power” and their “glorious ally,” Egypt! And they will say, “If this can happen to Egypt, what chance have we?”

1.verse: This is God’s message concerning Babylon: Disaster is roaring down upon you from the terrible desert, like a whirlwind sweeping from the Negeb.

2.verse: I see an awesome vision: oh, the horror of it all! God is telling me what he is going to do. I see you plundered and destroyed. Elamites and Medes will take part in the siege. Babylon will fall, and the groaning of all the nations she enslaved will end.

3.verse: My stomach constricts and burns with pain; sharp pangs of horror are upon me, like the pangs of a woman giving birth to a child. I faint when I hear what God is planning; I am terrified, blinded with dismay.

4.verse: My mind reels; my heart races; I am gripped by awful fear. All rest at night—so pleasant once—is gone; I lie awake, trembling.

5.verse: Look! They are preparing a great banquet! They load the tables with food; they pull up their chairs to eat. . . . Quick, quick, grab your shields and prepare for battle! You are being attacked!*

6.verse: Meanwhile (in my vision) the Lord had told me, “Put a watchman on the city wall to shout out what he sees. When he sees riders in pairs on donkeys and camels,* tell him, ‘This is it!’”

7.verse: Meanwhile (in my vision) the Lord had told me, “Put a watchman on the city wall to shout out what he sees. When he sees riders in pairs on donkeys and camels,* tell him, ‘This is it!’”

8.verse: So I put the watchman on the wall, and at last he shouted, “Sir, day after day and night after night I have been here at my post. Now at last—look! Here come riders in pairs!” Then I heard a voice shout out, “Babylon is fallen, is fallen; and all the idols of Babylon lie broken on the ground.”

9.verse: So I put the watchman on the wall, and at last he shouted, “Sir, day after day and night after night I have been here at my post. Now at last—look! Here come riders in pairs!” Then I heard a voice shout out, “Babylon is fallen, is fallen; and all the idols of Babylon lie broken on the ground.”

10.verse: O my people, threshed and winnowed, I have told you all that the Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, has said.

11.verse: This is God’s message to Edom: Someone from among you keeps calling, calling to me: “Watchman, what of the night? Watchman, what of the night? How much time is left?”

12.verse: The watchman replies, “Your judgment day is dawning now. Turn again to God, so that I can give you better news. Seek for him, then come and ask again!”

13.verse: This is God’s message concerning Arabia: O caravans from Dedan, you will hide in the deserts of Arabia.

14.verse: O people of Tema, bring food and water to these weary fugitives!

15.verse: They have fled from drawn swords and sharp arrows and the terrors of war!

16.verse: “But a long year from now,” says the Lord, “the great power of their enemy,* the mighty tribe of Kedar, will end.

17.verse: Only a few of its stalwart archers will survive.” The Lord, the God of Israel, has spoken.

1.verse: This is God’s message concerning Jerusalem: What is happening? Where is everyone going? Why are they running to the rooftops? What are they looking at?

2.verse: The whole city is in terrible uproar. What’s the trouble in this busy, happy city? Bodies! Lying everywhere, slain by plague* and not by sword.

3.verse: All your leaders flee; they surrender without resistance. The people slip away but they are captured too.

4.verse: Leave me alone to weep. Don’t try to comfort me—let me cry for my people as I watch them being destroyed.

5.verse: Oh, what a day of crushing trouble! What a day of confusion and terror from the Lord God of heaven’s armies! The walls of Jerusalem are breached, and the cry of death echoes from the mountainsides.

6.verse: Elamites are the archers; Syrians drive the chariots; the men of Kir hold up the shields. They fill your choicest valleys and crowd against your gates.

7.verse: Elamites are the archers; Syrians drive the chariots; the men of Kir hold up the shields. They fill your choicest valleys and crowd against your gates.

8.verse: God has removed his protecting care. You run to the armory for your weapons!

9.verse: You inspect the walls of Jerusalem to see what needs repair! You check over the houses and tear some down for stone for fixing walls. Between the city walls, you build a reservoir for water from the lower pool! But all your feverish plans will not avail, for you never ask for help from God, who lets this come upon you. He is the one who planned it long ago.

Between the city walls, you build a reservoir for water from the lower pool! But all your feverish plans will not avail, for you never ask for help from God, who lets this come upon you. He is the one who planned it long ago.

12.verse: The Lord God called you to repent, to weep and mourn, to shave your heads in sorrow for your sins, and to wear clothes made of sackcloth to show your remorse.

13.verse: But instead, you sing and dance and play, and feast and drink. “Let us eat, drink, and be merry,” you say: “What’s the difference, for tomorrow we die.”

14.verse: The Lord Almighty has revealed to me that this sin will never be forgiven you until the day you die.

15.verse: Furthermore, the same Lord God of the armies of heaven has told me this: Go and say to Shebna, the palace administrator: “And who do you think you are, building this beautiful sepulchre in the rock for yourself?

16.verse: Furthermore, the same Lord God of the armies of heaven has told me this: Go and say to Shebna, the palace administrator: “And who do you think you are, building this beautiful sepulchre in the rock for yourself?

17.verse: For the Lord who allowed you to be clothed so gorgeously will hurl you away, sending you into captivity, O strong man!

18.verse: He will wad you up in his hands like a ball and toss you away into a distant, barren land; there you will die, O glorious one—you who disgrace your nation!

19.verse: “Yes, I will drive you out of office,” says the Lord, “and pull you down from your high position.

20.verse: And then I will call my servant Eliakim, the son of Hilkiah, to replace you.

21.verse: He shall have your uniform and title and authority, and he will be a father to the people of Jerusalem and all Judah.

22.verse: I will give him responsibility over all my people; whatever he says will be done; none will be able to stop him.

23.verse: I will make of him a strong and steady peg to support my people; they will load him with responsibility, and he will be an honor to his family name.”

24.verse: I will make of him a strong and steady peg to support my people; they will load him with responsibility, and he will be an honor to his family name.”

25.verse: But the Lord will pull out that other peg that seems to be so firmly fastened to the wall! It will come out and fall to the ground, and everything it supports will fall with it, for the Lord has spoken.

1.verse: This is God’s message to Tyre: Weep, O ships of Tyre, returning home from distant lands! Weep for your harbor, for it is gone! The rumors that you heard in Cyprus are all true.

2.verse: Deathly silence is everywhere. Stillness reigns where once your hustling port was full of ships from Sidon, bringing merchandise from far across the ocean, from Egypt and along the Nile. You were the merchandise mart of the world.

3.verse: Deathly silence is everywhere. Stillness reigns where once your hustling port was full of ships from Sidon, bringing merchandise from far across the ocean, from Egypt and along the Nile. You were the merchandise mart of the world.

4.verse: Be ashamed, O Sidon,* stronghold of the sea. For you are childless now!

5.verse: When Egypt hears the news, there will be great sorrow.

6.verse: Flee to Tarshish, men of Tyre, weeping as you go.

7.verse: This silent ruin is all that’s left of your once joyous land. What a history was yours! Think of all the colonists you sent to distant lands!

8.verse: Who has brought this disaster on Tyre, empire builder and top trader of the world?

9.verse: The Commander of the armies of heaven has done it to destroy your pride and show his contempt for all the greatness of mankind.

10.verse: Sail on, O ships of Tarshish, for your harbor is gone.

11.verse: The Lord holds out his hand over the seas; he shakes the kingdoms of the earth; he has spoken out against this great merchant city, to destroy its strength.

12.verse: He says, “Never again, O dishonored virgin, daughter of Sidon, will you rejoice, will you be strong. Even if you flee to Cyprus, you will find no rest.”

13.verse: It will be the Babylonians, not the Assyrians, who consign Tyre to the wild beasts. They will lay siege to it, raze its palaces, and make it a heap of ruins.

14.verse: Wail, you ships that ply the oceans, for your home port is destroyed!

15.verse: For seventy years Tyre will be forgotten. Then, in the days of another king, the city will come back to life again; she will sing sweet songs as a harlot sings who, long absent from her lovers, walks the streets to look for them again and is remembered.

16.verse: For seventy years Tyre will be forgotten. Then, in the days of another king, the city will come back to life again; she will sing sweet songs as a harlot sings who, long absent from her lovers, walks the streets to look for them again and is remembered.

17.verse: Yes, after seventy years, the Lord will revive Tyre, but she will be no different than she was before; she will return again to all her evil ways around the world.

18.verse: Yet the distant time will come when her businesses will give their profits to the Lord! They will not be hoarded but used for good food and fine clothes for the priests of the Lord!

1.verse: Look! The Lord is overturning the land of Judah and making it a vast wasteland of destruction. See how he is emptying out all its people and scattering them over the face of the earth.

2.verse: Priests and people, servants and masters, slave girls and mistresses, buyers and sellers, lenders and borrowers, bankers and debtors—none will be spared.

3.verse: The land will be completely emptied and looted. The Lord has spoken.

4.verse: The land suffers for the sins of its people. The earth languishes, the crops wither, the skies refuse their rain. The land is defiled by crime; the people have twisted the laws of God and broken his everlasting commands.

5.verse: The land suffers for the sins of its people. The earth languishes, the crops wither, the skies refuse their rain. The land is defiled by crime; the people have twisted the laws of God and broken his everlasting commands.

6.verse: Therefore the curse of God is upon them; they are left desolate, destroyed by the drought. Few will be left alive.

7.verse: All the joys of life will go: the grape harvest will fail, the wine will be gone, the merrymakers will sigh and mourn.

8.verse: The melodious chords of the harp and timbrel are heard no more; the happy days are ended.

9.verse: No more are the joys of wine and song; strong drink turns bitter in the mouth.

10.verse: The city lies in chaos; every home and shop is locked up tight to keep out looters.

11.verse: Mobs form in the streets, crying for wine; joy has reached its lowest ebb; gladness has been banished from the land.

12.verse: The city is left in ruins; its gates are battered down.

13.verse: Throughout the land the story is the same—only a remnant is left.

14.verse: But all who are left will shout and sing for joy; those in the west will praise the majesty of God,

15.verse: and those in the east will respond with praise. Hear them singing to the Lord from the ends of the earth, singing glory to the Righteous One! But my heart is heavy with grief, for evil still prevails and treachery is everywhere.

16.verse: and those in the east will respond with praise. Hear them singing to the Lord from the ends of the earth, singing glory to the Righteous One! But my heart is heavy with grief, for evil still prevails and treachery is everywhere.

17.verse: Terror and the captivity of hell are still your lot, O men of the world.

18.verse: When you flee in terror, you will fall into a pit, and if you escape from the pit, you will step into a trap, for destruction falls from the heavens upon you; the world is shaken beneath you.

19.verse: The earth has broken down in utter collapse; everything is lost, abandoned, and confused.

20.verse: The world staggers like a drunkard; it shakes like a tent in a storm. It falls and will not rise again, for the sins of the earth are very great.

21.verse: On that day the Lord will punish the fallen angels in the heavens and the proud rulers of the nations on earth.

22.verse: They will be rounded up like prisoners and imprisoned in a dungeon until they are tried and condemned.

23.verse: Then the Lord of heaven’s armies will mount his throne in Zion and rule gloriously in Jerusalem, in the sight of all the elders of his people. Such glory there will be that all the brightness of the sun and moon will seem to fade away.

1.verse: O Lord, I will honor and praise your name, for you are my God; you do such wonderful things! You planned them long ago, and now you have accomplished them, just as you said!

2.verse: You turn mighty cities into heaps of ruins. The strongest forts are turned to rubble. Beautiful palaces in distant lands disappear and will never be rebuilt.

3.verse: Therefore strong nations will shake with fear before you; ruthless nations will obey and glorify your name.

4.verse: But to the poor, O Lord, you are a refuge from the storm, a shadow from the heat, a shelter from merciless men who are like a driving rain that melts down an earthen wall.

5.verse: As a hot, dry land is cooled by clouds, you will cool the pride of ruthless nations.

6.verse: Here on Mount Zion in Jerusalem, the Lord Almighty will spread a wondrous feast for everyone around the world—a delicious feast of good food, with clear, well-aged wine and choice beef.

7.verse: At that time he will remove the cloud of gloom, the pall of death that hangs over the earth;

8.verse: he will swallow up death forever. The Lord God will wipe away all tears and take away forever all insults and mockery against his land and people. The Lord has spoken—he will surely do it!

9.verse: In that day the people will proclaim, “This is our God in whom we trust, for whom we waited. Now at last he is here.” What a day of rejoicing!

10.verse: For the Lord’s good hand will rest upon Jerusalem, and Moab will be crushed as straw beneath his feet and left to rot.

11.verse: God will push them down just as a swimmer pushes down the water with his hands. He will end their pride and all their evil works.

12.verse: The high walls of Moab will be demolished and brought to dust.

1.verse: Listen to them singing! In that day the whole land of Judah will sing this song: “Our city is strong! We are surrounded by the walls of his salvation!”

2.verse: Open the gates to everyone, for all may enter in who love the Lord.

3.verse: He will keep in perfect peace all those who trust in him, whose thoughts turn often to the Lord!

4.verse: Trust in the Lord God always, for in the Lord Jehovah is your everlasting strength.

5.verse: He humbles the proud and brings the haughty city to the dust; its walls come crashing down.

6.verse: He presents it to the poor and needy for their use.

7.verse: But for good men the path is not uphill and rough! God does not give them a rough and treacherous path, but smooths the road before them.

8.verse: O Lord, we love to do your will! Our hearts’ desire is to glorify your name.

9.verse: All night long I search for you; earnestly I seek for God; for only when you come in judgment on the earth to punish it will people turn away from wickedness and do what is right.

10.verse: Your kindness to the wicked doesn’t make them good; they keep on doing wrong and take no notice of your majesty.

11.verse: They do not listen when you threaten; they will not look to see your upraised fist. Show them how much you love your people. Perhaps then they will be ashamed! Yes, let them be burned up by the fire reserved for your enemies.

12.verse: Lord, grant us peace; for all we have and are has come from you.

13.verse: O Lord our God, once we worshiped other gods; but now we worship you alone.

14.verse: Those we served before are dead and gone; never again will they return. You came against them and destroyed them, and they are long forgotten.

15.verse: O praise the Lord! He has made our nation very great. He has widened the boundaries of our land!

16.verse: Lord, in their distress they sought for you. When your punishment was on them, they poured forth a whispered prayer.

17.verse: How we missed your presence, Lord! We suffered as a woman giving birth who cries and writhes in pain.

18.verse: We too have writhed in agony, but all to no avail. No deliverance has come from all our efforts.

19.verse: Yet we have this assurance: Those who belong to God shall live again. Their bodies shall rise again! Those who dwell in the dust shall awake and sing for joy! For God’s light of life will fall like dew upon them!

20.verse: Go home, my people, and lock the doors! Hide for a little while until the Lord’s wrath against your enemies has passed.

21.verse: Look! The Lord is coming from the heavens to punish the people of the earth for their sins. The earth will no longer hide the murderers. The guilty will be found.

1.verse: In that day the Lord will take his terrible, swift sword and punish leviathan, the swiftly moving serpent, the coiling, writhing serpent, the dragon of the sea.

2.verse: In that day of Israel’s freedom let this anthem be their song:

3.verse: Israel is my vineyard; I, the Lord, will tend the fruitful vines; every day I’ll water them, and day and night I’ll watch to keep all enemies away.

4.verse: My anger against Israel* is gone. If I find thorns and briars bothering her, I will burn them up, unless these enemies of mine surrender and beg for peace and my protection.

5.verse: My anger against Israel* is gone. If I find thorns and briars bothering her, I will burn them up, unless these enemies of mine surrender and beg for peace and my protection.

6.verse: The time will come when Israel will take root and bud and blossom and fill the whole earth with her fruit!

7.verse: Has God punished Israel as much as he has punished her enemies? No, for he has devastated her enemies, while he has punished Israel but a little, exiling her far from her own land as though blown away in a storm from the east.

8.verse: Has God punished Israel as much as he has punished her enemies? No, for he has devastated her enemies, while he has punished Israel but a little, exiling her far from her own land as though blown away in a storm from the east.

9.verse: And why did God do it? It was to purge away her sins, to rid her of all her idol altars and her idols. They will never be worshiped again.

10.verse: Her walled cities will be silent and empty, houses abandoned, streets grown up with grass, cows grazing through the city munching on twigs and branches.

11.verse: My people are like the dead branches of a tree, broken off and used to burn beneath the pots. They are a foolish nation, a witless, stupid people, for they turn away from God. Therefore, he who made them will not have pity on them or show them his mercy.

12.verse: Yet the time will come when the Lord will gather them together one by one like hand-picked grain, selecting them here and there from his great threshing floor that reaches all the way from the Euphrates River to the Egyptian boundary.

13.verse: In that day the great trumpet will be blown, and many about to perish among their enemies, Assyria and Egypt, will be rescued and brought back to Jerusalem to worship the Lord in his holy mountain.

1.verse: Woe to the city of Samaria, surrounded by her rich valley—Samaria, the pride and delight of the drunkards of Israel! Woe to her fading beauty, the crowning glory of a nation of men lying drunk in the streets!

2.verse: For the Lord will send a mighty army (the Assyrians) against you; like a mighty hailstorm he will burst upon you and dash you to the ground.

3.verse: The proud city of Samaria—yes, the joy and delight of the drunkards of Israel—will be hurled to the ground and trampled beneath the enemies’ feet.
