4.verse: Once glorious, her fading beauty surrounded by a fertile valley will suddenly be gone, greedily snatched away as an early fig is hungrily snatched and gobbled up!

5.verse: Then at last the Lord Almighty himself will be their crowning glory, the diadem of beauty to his people who are left.

6.verse: He will give a longing for justice to your judges and great courage to your soldiers who are battling to the last before your gates.

7.verse: But Jerusalem is now led by drunks! Her priests and prophets reel and stagger, making stupid errors and mistakes.

8.verse: Their tables are covered with vomit; filth is everywhere.

9.verse: “Who does Isaiah think he is,” the people say, “to speak to us like this! Are we little children, barely old enough to talk?

10.verse: He tells us everything over and over again, a line at a time and in such simple words!”

11.verse: But they won’t listen; the only language they can understand is punishment! So God will punish them by sending against them foreigners who speak strange gibberish! Only then will they listen to him!

12.verse: They could have rest in their own land if they would obey him, if they were kind and good. He told them that, but they wouldn’t listen to him.

13.verse: So the Lord will spell it out for them again, repeating it over and over in simple words whenever he can; yet over this simple, straightforward message they will stumble and fall and be broken, trapped and captured.

14.verse: Therefore hear the word of the Lord, you scoffing rulers in Jerusalem:

15.verse: You have struck a bargain with death, you say, and sold yourselves to the devil in exchange for his protection against the Assyrians. “They can never touch us,” you say, “for we are under the care of one who will deceive and fool them.”

16.verse: But the Lord God says, “See, I am placing a Foundation Stone in Zion—a firm, tested, precious Cornerstone that is safe to build on. He who believes need never run away again.

17.verse: I will take the line and plummet of justice to check the foundation wall you built; it looks so fine, but it is so weak a storm of hail will knock it down! The enemy will come like a flood and sweep it away, and you will be drowned.

18.verse: I will cancel your agreement of compromise with death and the devil, so when the terrible enemy floods in, you will be trampled into the ground.

19.verse: Again and again that flood will come and carry you off, until at last the unmixed horror of the truth of my warnings will finally dawn on you.”

20.verse: The bed you have made is far too short to lie on; the blankets are too narrow to cover you.

21.verse: The Lord will come suddenly and in anger, as at Mount Perazim and Gibeon, to do a strange, unusual thing—to destroy his own people!

22.verse: So scoff no more, lest your punishment be made even greater, for the Lord God has plainly told me that he is determined to crush you.

23.verse: Listen to me, listen as I plead: Does a farmer always plow and never sow? Is he forever harrowing the soil and never planting it?

24.verse: Listen to me, listen as I plead: Does a farmer always plow and never sow? Is he forever harrowing the soil and never planting it?

25.verse: Does he not finally plant his many kinds of grain, each in its own section of his land?

26.verse: He knows just what to do, for God has made him see and understand.

27.verse: He doesn’t thresh all grains the same. A sledge is never used on dill, but it is beaten with a stick. A threshing wheel is never rolled on cummin, but it is beaten softly with a flail.

28.verse: Bread grain is easily crushed, so he doesn’t keep on pounding it.

29.verse: The Lord Almighty is a wonderful teacher and gives the farmer wisdom.

1.verse: Woe to Jerusalem, the city of David. Year after year you make your many offerings,

2.verse: but I will send heavy judgment upon you, and there will be weeping and sorrow. For Jerusalem shall become as her name “Ariel” means—an altar covered with blood.

3.verse: I will be your enemy. I will surround Jerusalem and lay siege against it, and build forts around it to destroy it.

4.verse: Your voice will whisper like a ghost from the earth where you lie buried.

5.verse: But suddenly your ruthless enemies will be driven away like chaff before the wind.

6.verse: In an instant, I, the Lord of Hosts, will come upon them with thunder, earthquake, whirlwind, and fire.

7.verse: And all the nations fighting Jerusalem will vanish like a dream!

8.verse: As a hungry man dreams of eating but is still hungry, and as a thirsty man dreams of drinking but is still faint from thirst when he wakes up, so your enemies will dream of victorious conquest, but all to no avail.

9.verse: You are amazed, incredulous? You don’t believe it? Then go ahead and be blind if you must! You are stupid—and not from drinking, either! Stagger, and not from wine!

10.verse: For the Lord has poured out upon you a spirit of deep sleep. He has closed the eyes of your prophets and seers,

11.verse: so all of these future events are a sealed book to them. When you give it to one who can read, he says, “I can’t, for it’s sealed.”

12.verse: When you give it to another, he says, “Sorry, I can’t read.”

13.verse: And so the Lord says, “Since these people say they are mine but they do not obey me, and since their worship amounts to mere words learned by rote,

14.verse: therefore I will take awesome vengeance on these hypocrites and make their wisest counselors as fools.”

15.verse: Woe to those who try to hide their plans from God, who try to keep him in the dark concerning what they do! “God can’t see us,” they say to themselves. “He doesn’t know what is going on!”

16.verse: How stupid can they be! Isn’t he, the Potter, greater than you, the jars he makes? Will you say to him, “He didn’t make us”? Does a machine call its inventor dumb?

17.verse: Soon—and it will not be very long—the wilderness of Lebanon will be a fruitful field again, a lush and fertile forest.

18.verse: In that day the deaf will hear the words of a book, and out of their gloom and darkness the blind will see my plans.

19.verse: The meek will be filled with fresh joy from the Lord, and the poor shall exult in the Holy One of Israel.

20.verse: Bullies will vanish and scoffers will cease, and all those plotting evil will be killed—

21.verse: the violent man who fights at the drop of a hat, the man who waits in hiding to beat up the judge who sentenced him, and the men who use any excuse to be unfair.

22.verse: That is why the Lord who redeemed Abraham says: “My people will no longer pale with fear or be ashamed.

23.verse: For when they see the surging birthrate and the expanding economy, then they will fear and rejoice in my name; they will praise the Holy One of Israel and stand in awe of him.

24.verse: Those in error will believe the truth, and complainers will be willing to be taught!

1.verse: Woe to my rebellious children, says the Lord; you ask advice from everyone but me and decide to do what I don’t want you to do. You yoke yourselves with unbelievers, thus piling up your sins.

2.verse: For without consulting me you have gone down to Egypt to find aid and have put your trust in Pharaoh for his protection.

3.verse: But in trusting Pharaoh, you will be disappointed, humiliated and disgraced, for he can’t deliver on his promises to save you.

4.verse: For though his power extends to Zoan and Hanes,

5.verse: yet it will all turn out to your shame—he won’t help one little bit!

6.verse: See them moving slowly across the terrible desert to Egypt—donkeys and camels laden down with treasure to pay for Egypt’s aid. On through the badlands they go, where lions and swift venomous snakes live—and Egypt will give you nothing in return!

7.verse: For Egypt’s promises are worthless! “The Reluctant Dragon,” I call her!

8.verse: Now go and write down this word of mine concerning Egypt, so that it will stand until the end of time, forever and forever, as an indictment of Israel’s unbelief.

9.verse: For if you don’t write it, they will claim I never warned them. “Oh no,” they’ll say, “you never told us that!” For they are stubborn rebels.

10.verse: They tell my prophets, “Shut up—we don’t want any more of your reports!” Or they say, “Don’t tell us the truth; tell us nice things; tell us lies. Forget all this gloom; we’ve heard more than enough about your ‘Holy One of Israel’ and all he says.”

11.verse: They tell my prophets, “Shut up—we don’t want any more of your reports!” Or they say, “Don’t tell us the truth; tell us nice things; tell us lies. Forget all this gloom; we’ve heard more than enough about your ‘Holy One of Israel’ and all he says.”

12.verse: This is the reply of the Holy One of Israel: Because you despise what I tell you and trust instead in frauds and lies and won’t repent,

13.verse: therefore calamity will come upon you suddenly, as upon a bulging wall that bursts and falls; in one moment it comes crashing down.

14.verse: God will smash you like a broken dish; he will not act sparingly. Not a piece will be left large enough to use for carrying coals from the hearth, or a little water from the well.

15.verse: For the Lord God, the Holy One of Israel, says: Only in returning to me and waiting for me will you be saved; in quietness and confidence is your strength; but you’ll have none of this.

16.verse: “No,” you say. “We will get our help from Egypt; they will give us swift horses for riding to battle.” But the only swiftness you are going to see is the swiftness of your enemies chasing you!

17.verse: One of them will chase a thousand of you! Five of them will scatter you until not two of you are left together. You will be like lonely trees on the distant mountaintops.

18.verse: Yet the Lord still waits for you to come to him so he can show you his love; he will conquer you to bless you, just as he said. For the Lord is faithful to his promises. Blessed are all those who wait for him to help them.

19.verse: O my people in Jerusalem, you shall weep no more, for he will surely be gracious to you at the sound of your cry. He will answer you.

20.verse: Though he give you the bread of adversity and water of affliction, yet he will be with you to teach you—with your own eyes you will see your Teacher.

21.verse: And if you leave God’s paths and go astray, you will hear a voice behind you say, “No, this is the way; walk here.”

22.verse: And you will destroy all your silver idols and gold images and cast them out like filthy things you hate to touch. “Ugh!” you’ll say to them. “Be gone!”

23.verse: Then God will bless you with rain at planting time and with wonderful harvests and with ample pastures for your cows.

24.verse: The oxen and young donkeys that till the ground will eat grain, its chaff blown away by the wind.

25.verse: In that day when God steps in to destroy your enemies, he will give you streams of water flowing down each mountain and every hill.

26.verse: The moon will be as bright as the sun, and the sunlight brighter than seven days! So it will be when the Lord begins to heal his people and to cure the wounds he gave them.

27.verse: See, the Lord comes from afar, aflame with wrath, surrounded by thick rising smoke. His lips are filled with fury; his words consume like fire.

28.verse: His wrath pours out like floods upon them all, to sweep them all away. He will sift out the proud nations and bridle them and lead them off to their doom.

29.verse: But the people of God will sing a song of solemn joy, like songs in the night when holy feasts are held; his people will have gladness of heart, as when a flutist leads a pilgrim band to Jerusalem to the mountain of the Lord, the Rock of Israel.

30.verse: And the Lord shall cause his majestic voice to be heard and shall crush down his mighty arm upon his enemies with angry indignation and devouring flames, with tornados, terrible storms, and huge hailstones.

31.verse: The voice of the Lord shall punish the Assyrians, who had been his rod of punishment.

32.verse: And when the Lord smites them, his people will rejoice with music and song.

33.verse: The funeral pyre has long been ready, prepared for Molech, the Assyrian god; it is piled high with wood. The breath of the Lord, like fire from a volcano, will set it all on fire.

1.verse: Woe to those who run to Egypt for help, trusting their mighty cavalry and chariots instead of looking to the Holy One of Israel and consulting him.

2.verse: In his wisdom, he will send great evil on his people and will not change his mind. He will rise against them for the evil they have done and crush their allies too.

3.verse: For these Egyptians are mere men, not God! Their horses are puny flesh, not mighty spirits! When the Lord clenches his fist against them, they will stumble and fall among those they are trying to help. All will fail together.

4.verse: But the Lord has told me this: When a lion, even a young one, kills a sheep, he pays no attention to the shepherd’s shouts and noise. He goes right on and eats. In such manner the Lord will come and fight upon Mount Zion. He will not be frightened away! He, the Lord Almighty, will hover over Jerusalem as birds hover round their nests, and he will defend the city and deliver it.

5.verse: But the Lord has told me this: When a lion, even a young one, kills a sheep, he pays no attention to the shepherd’s shouts and noise. He goes right on and eats. In such manner the Lord will come and fight upon Mount Zion. He will not be frightened away! He, the Lord Almighty, will hover over Jerusalem as birds hover round their nests, and he will defend the city and deliver it.

6.verse: Therefore, O my people, though you are such wicked rebels, come, return to God.

7.verse: I know the glorious day will come when every one of you will throw away his gold idols and silver images—which in your sinfulness you have made.

8.verse: The Assyrians will be destroyed, but not by swords of men. The “sword of God” will smite them. They will panic and flee, and the strong young Assyrians will be taken away as slaves.

9.verse: Even their generals will quake with terror and flee when they see the battle flags of Israel, says the Lord. For the flame of God burns brightly in Jerusalem.

1.verse: Look, a righteous King is coming, with honest princes!

2.verse: He will shelter Israel from the storm and wind. He will refresh her as a river in the desert and as the cooling shadow of a mighty rock within a hot and weary land.

3.verse: Then at last the eyes of Israel will open wide to God; his people will listen to his voice.

4.verse: Even the hotheads among them will be full of sense and understanding, and those who stammer in uncertainty will speak out plainly.

5.verse: In those days the ungodly, the atheists, will not be heroes! Wealthy cheaters will not be spoken of as generous, outstanding men!

6.verse: Everyone will recognize an evil man when he sees him, and hypocrites will fool no one at all. Their lies about God and their cheating of the hungry will be plain for all to see.

7.verse: The smooth tricks of evil men will be exposed, as will all the lies they use to oppress the poor in the courts.

8.verse: But good men will be generous to others and will be blessed of God for all they do.

9.verse: Listen, you women who loll around in lazy ease; listen to me and I will tell you your reward:

10.verse: In a short time—in just a little more than a year—suddenly you’ll care, O careless ones. For the crops of fruit will fail; the harvest will not take place.

11.verse: Tremble, O women of ease; throw off your unconcern. Strip off your pretty clothes—wear sackcloth for your grief.

12.verse: Beat your breasts in sorrow for those bountiful farms of yours that will soon be gone, and for those fruitful vines of other years.

13.verse: For your lands will thrive with thorns and briars; your joyous homes and happy cities will be gone.

14.verse: Palaces and mansions will all be deserted, the crowded cities empty. Wild herds of donkeys and goats will graze upon the mountains where the watchtowers are,

15.verse: until at last the Spirit is poured down on us from heaven. Then once again enormous crops will come.

16.verse: Then justice will rule through all the land,

17.verse: and out of justice, peace. Quietness and confidence will reign forever more.

18.verse: My people will live in safety, quietly at home,

19.verse: but the Assyrians will be destroyed and their cities laid low.

20.verse: And God will greatly bless his people. Wherever they plant, bountiful crops will spring up, and their flocks and herds will graze in green pastures.

1.verse: Woe to you, Assyrians, who have destroyed everything around you but have never felt destruction for yourselves. You expect others to respect their promises to you, while you betray them! Now you, too, will be betrayed and destroyed.

2.verse: But to us, O Lord, be merciful, for we have waited for you. Be our strength each day and our salvation in the time of trouble.

3.verse: The enemy runs at the sound of your voice. When you stand up, the nations flee.

4.verse: Just as locusts strip the fields and vines, so Jerusalem will strip the fallen army of Assyria!

5.verse: The Lord is very great and lives in heaven. He will make Jerusalem the home of justice and goodness and righteousness.

6.verse: An abundance of salvation is stored up for Judah in a safe place, along with wisdom and knowledge and reverence for God.

7.verse: But now your ambassadors weep in bitter disappointment, for Assyria has refused their cry for peace.

8.verse: Your roads lie in ruins; travelers detour on back roads. The Assyrians have broken their peace pact and care nothing for the promises they made in the presence of witnesses—they have no respect for anyone.

9.verse: All the land of Israel is in trouble; Lebanon has been destroyed; Sharon has become a wilderness; Bashan and Carmel are plundered.

10.verse: But the Lord says: I will stand up and show my power and might.

11.verse: You Assyrians will gain nothing by all your efforts. Your own breath will turn to fire and kill you.

12.verse: Your armies will be burned to lime, like thorns cut down and tossed in the fire.

13.verse: Listen to what I have done, O nations far away! And you that are near, acknowledge my might!

14.verse: The sinners among my people shake with fear. “Which one of us,” they cry, “can live here in the presence of this all-consuming, everlasting fire?”

15.verse: I will tell you who can live here: All who are honest and fair, who reject making profit by fraud, who hold back their hands from taking bribes, who refuse to listen to those who plot murder, who shut their eyes to all enticement to do wrong.

16.verse: Such as these shall dwell on high. The rocks of the mountains will be their fortress of safety; food will be supplied to them, and they will have all the water they need.

17.verse: Your eyes will see the King in his beauty and the highlands of heaven far away.

18.verse: Your mind will think back to this time of terror when the Assyrian officers outside your walls are counting your towers and estimating how much they will get from your fallen city.

19.verse: But soon they will all be gone. These fierce, violent people with a strange, jabbering language you can’t understand will disappear.

20.verse: Instead you will see Jerusalem at peace, a place where God is worshiped, a city quiet and unmoved.

21.verse: The glorious Lord will be to us as a wide river of protection, and no enemy can cross.

22.verse: For the Lord is our Judge, our Lawgiver and our King; he will care for us and save us.

23.verse: The enemies’ sails hang loose on broken masts with useless tackle. Their treasure will be divided by the people of God; even the lame will win their share.

24.verse: The people of Israel will no longer say, “We are sick and helpless,” for the Lord will forgive them their sins and bless them.

1.verse: Come here and listen, O nations of the earth; let the world and everything in it hear my words.

2.verse: For the Lord is enraged against the nations; his fury is against their armies. He will utterly destroy them and deliver them to slaughter.

3.verse: Their dead will be left unburied, and the stench of rotting bodies will fill the land; the mountains will flow with their blood.

4.verse: At that time the heavens above will melt away and disappear just like a rolled-up scroll, and the stars will fall as leaves, as ripe fruit from the trees.

5.verse: And when my sword has finished its work in the heavens, then watch, for it will fall upon Edom, the people I have doomed.

6.verse: The sword of the Lord is sated with blood; it is gorged with flesh as though used for slaying lambs and goats for sacrifice. For the Lord will slay a great sacrifice in Edom and make a mighty slaughter there.

7.verse: The strongest will perish, young boys and veterans too. The land will be soaked with blood, and the soil made rich with fat.

8.verse: For it is the day of vengeance, the year of recompense for what Edom has done to Israel.

9.verse: The streams of Edom will be filled with burning pitch, and the ground will be covered with fire.

10.verse: This judgment on Edom will never end. Its smoke will rise up forever. The land will lie deserted from generation to generation; no one will live there anymore.

11.verse: There the hawks and porcupines will live, and owls and ravens. For God will observe that land and find it worthy of destruction. He will test its nobles and find them worthy of death.

12.verse: It will be called “The Land of Nothing,” and its princes soon will all be gone.

13.verse: Thorns will overrun the palaces, nettles will grow in its forts, and it will become the haunt of jackals and a home for ostriches.

14.verse: The wild animals of the desert will mingle there with wolves and hyenas. Their howls will fill the night. There the night-monsters will scream at each other, and the demons will come there to rest.

15.verse: There the owl will make her nest and lay her eggs; she will hatch her young and nestle them beneath her wings, and the kites will come, each one with its mate.

16.verse: Search the book of the Lord and see all that he will do; not one detail will he miss; not one kite will be there without a mate, for the Lord has said it, and his Spirit will make it all come true.

17.verse: He has surveyed and subdivided the land and deeded it to those doleful creatures; they shall possess it forever, from generation to generation.

1.verse: Even the wilderness and desert will rejoice in those days; the desert will blossom with flowers.

2.verse: Yes, there will be an abundance of flowers and singing and joy! The deserts will become as green as the Lebanon mountains, as lovely as Mount Carmel’s pastures and Sharon’s meadows; for the Lord will display his glory there, the excellency of our God.

3.verse: With this news bring cheer to all discouraged ones.

4.verse: Encourage those who are afraid. Tell them, “Be strong, fear not, for your God is coming to destroy your enemies. He is coming to save you.”

5.verse: And when he comes, he will open the eyes of the blind and unstop the ears of the deaf.

6.verse: The lame man will leap up like a deer, and those who could not speak will shout and sing! Springs will burst forth in the wilderness, and streams in the desert.

7.verse: The parched ground will become a pool, with springs of water in the thirsty land. Where desert jackals lived, there will be reeds and rushes!

8.verse: And a main road will go through that once-deserted land; it will be named “The Holy Highway.” No evil-hearted men may walk upon it. God will walk there with you; even the most stupid cannot miss the way.

9.verse: No lion will lurk along its course, nor will there be any other dangers; only the redeemed will travel there.

10.verse: These, the ransomed of the Lord, will go home along that road to Zion, singing the songs of everlasting joy. For them all sorrow and all sighing will be gone forever; only joy and gladness will be there.

1.verse: So in the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah’s reign, Sennacherib, king of Assyria, came to fight against the walled cities of Judah and conquered them.

2.verse: Then he sent his personal representative with a great army from Lachish to confer with King Hezekiah in Jerusalem. He camped near the outlet of the upper pool, along the road going past the field where cloth is bleached.

3.verse: Then Eliakim, Hilkiah’s son, who was the prime minister of Israel, and Shebna, the king’s scribe, and Joah, Asaph’s son, the royal secretary, formed a truce team and went out of the city to meet with him.

4.verse: The Assyrian ambassador told them to go and say to Hezekiah, “The mighty king of Assyria says you are a fool to think that the king of Egypt will help you.

5.verse: What are the Pharaoh’s promises worth? Mere words won’t substitute for strength, yet you rely on him for help and have rebelled against me!

6.verse: Egypt is a dangerous ally. She is a sharpened stick that will pierce your hand if you lean on it. That is the experience of everyone who has ever looked to her for help.

7.verse: But perhaps you say, ‘We are trusting in the Lord our God!’ Oh? Isn’t he the one your king insulted, tearing down his temples and altars in the hills and making everyone in Judah worship only at the altars here in Jerusalem?

8.verse: My master, the king of Assyria, wants to make a little bet with you!—that you don’t have 2,000 men left in your entire army! If you do, he will give you 2,000 horses for them to ride on! With that tiny army, how can you think of proceeding against even the smallest and worst contingent of my master’s troops? For you’ll get no help from Egypt.

9.verse: My master, the king of Assyria, wants to make a little bet with you!—that you don’t have 2,000 men left in your entire army! If you do, he will give you 2,000 horses for them to ride on! With that tiny army, how can you think of proceeding against even the smallest and worst contingent of my master’s troops? For you’ll get no help from Egypt.

10.verse: What’s more, do you think I have come here without the Lord’s telling me to take this land? The Lord said to me, ‘Go and destroy it!’”

11.verse: Then Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah said to him, “Please talk to us in Aramaic, for we understand it quite well. Don’t speak in Hebrew, for the people on the wall will hear.”

12.verse: But he replied, “My master wants everyone in Jerusalem to hear this, not just you. He wants them to know that if you don’t surrender, this city will be put under siege until everyone is so hungry and thirsty that he will eat his own dung and drink his own urine.”

13.verse: Then he shouted in Hebrew to the Jews listening on the wall, “Hear the words of the great king, the king of Assyria:

14.verse: “Don’t let Hezekiah fool you—nothing he can do will save you.

15.verse: Don’t let him talk you into trusting in the Lord by telling you the Lord won’t let you be conquered by the king of Assyria.

16.verse: Don’t listen to Hezekiah, for here is the king of Assyria’s offer to you: Give me a present as a token of surrender; open the gates and come out, and I will let you each have your own farm and garden and water,

17.verse: until I can arrange to take you to a country very similar to this one—a country where there are bountiful harvests of grain and grapes, a land of plenty.

18.verse: Don’t let Hezekiah deprive you of all this by saying the Lord will deliver you from my armies. Have any other nation’s gods ever gained victory over the armies of the king of Assyria?

19.verse: Don’t you remember what I did to Hamath and Arpad? Did their gods save them? And what about Sepharvaim and Samaria? Where are their gods now?

20.verse: Of all the gods of these lands, which one has ever delivered their people from my power? Name just one! And do you think this God of yours can deliver Jerusalem from me? Don’t be ridiculous!”

21.verse: But the people were silent and answered not a word, for Hezekiah had told them to say nothing in reply.

22.verse: Then Eliakim (son of Hilkiah), the prime minister, and Shebna, the royal scribe, and Joah (son of Asaph), the royal secretary, went back to Hezekiah with clothes ripped to shreds as a sign of their despair and told him all that had happened.

1.verse: When King Hezekiah heard the results of the meeting, he tore his robes and wound himself in coarse cloth used for making sacks, as a sign of humility and mourning, and went over to the Temple to pray.

2.verse: Meanwhile he sent Eliakim his prime minister, and Shebna his royal scribe, and the older priests—all dressed in sackcloth—to Isaiah the prophet, son of Amoz.

3.verse: They brought him this message from Hezekiah: “This is a day of trouble and frustration and blasphemy; it is a serious time, as when a woman is in heavy labor trying to give birth and the child does not come.

4.verse: But perhaps the Lord your God heard the blasphemy of the king of Assyria’s representative as he scoffed at the living God. Surely God won’t let him get away with this. Surely God will rebuke him for those words. Oh, Isaiah, pray for us who are left!”

5.verse: So they took the king’s message to Isaiah.

6.verse: Then Isaiah replied, “Tell King Hezekiah that the Lord says: Don’t be disturbed by this speech from the servant of the king of Assyria and his blasphemy.

7.verse: For a report from Assyria will reach the king that he is needed at home at once, and he will return to his own land, where I will have him killed.”

8.verse: Now the Assyrian envoy left Jerusalem and went to consult his king, who had left Lachish and was besieging Libnah. But at this point the Assyrian king received word that Tirhakah, crown prince of Ethiopia, was leading an army against him from the south. Upon hearing this, he sent messengers back to Jerusalem to Hezekiah with this message:

9.verse: Now the Assyrian envoy left Jerusalem and went to consult his king, who had left Lachish and was besieging Libnah. But at this point the Assyrian king received word that Tirhakah, crown prince of Ethiopia, was leading an army against him from the south. Upon hearing this, he sent messengers back to Jerusalem to Hezekiah with this message:

10.verse: “Don’t let this God you trust in fool you by promising that Jerusalem will not be captured by the king of Assyria!

11.verse: Just remember what has happened wherever the kings of Assyria have gone, for they have crushed everyone who has opposed them. Do you think you will be any different?

12.verse: Did their gods save the cities of Gozan, Haran, or Rezeph, or the people of Eden in Telassar? No, the Assyrian kings completely destroyed them!

13.verse: And don’t forget what happened to the king of Hamath, to the king of Arpad, and to the kings of the cities of Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivvah.”

14.verse: As soon as King Hezekiah had read this letter, he went over to the Temple and spread it out before the Lord

15.verse: and prayed, saying,

16.verse: “O Lord, Almighty God of Israel enthroned between the Guardian Angels, you alone are God of all the kingdoms of the earth. You alone made heaven and earth. Listen as I plead; see me as I pray. Look at this letter from King Sennacherib, for he has mocked the living God.

17.verse: “O Lord, Almighty God of Israel enthroned between the Guardian Angels, you alone are God of all the kingdoms of the earth. You alone made heaven and earth. Listen as I plead; see me as I pray. Look at this letter from King Sennacherib, for he has mocked the living God.

18.verse: It is true, O Lord, that the kings of Assyria have destroyed all those nations, just as the letter says,

19.verse: and thrown their gods into the fire; for they weren’t gods at all but merely idols, carved by men from wood and stone. Of course the Assyrians could destroy them.

20.verse: O Lord our God, save us so that all the kingdoms of the earth will know that you are God, and you alone.”

21.verse: Then Isaiah, the son of Amoz, sent this message to King Hezekiah: “The Lord God of Israel says: This is my answer to your prayer against Sennacherib, Assyria’s king.

22.verse: “The Lord says to him: My people—the helpless virgin daughter of Zion—laughs at you and scoffs and shakes her head at you in scorn.

23.verse: Who is it you scoffed against and mocked? Whom did you revile? At whom did you direct your violence and pride? It was against the Holy One of Israel!

24.verse: You have sent your messengers to mock the Lord. You boast, ‘I came with my mighty army against the nations of the west. I cut down the tallest cedars and choicest cypress trees. I conquered their highest mountains and destroyed their thickest forests.’

25.verse: “You boast of wells you’ve dug in many a conquered land, and Egypt with all its armies is no obstacle to you!

26.verse: But do you not yet know that it was I who decided all this long ago? That it was I who gave you all this power from ancient times? I have caused all this to happen as I planned—that you should crush walled cities into ruined heaps.

27.verse: That’s why their people had so little power and were such easy prey for you. They were as helpless as the grass, as tender plants you trample down beneath your feet, as grass upon the housetops, burnt yellow by the sun.

28.verse: But I know you well—your comings and goings and all you do—and the way you have raged against me.

29.verse: Because of your anger against the Lord—and I heard it all!—I have put a hook in your nose and a bit in your mouth and led you back to your own land by the same road you came.”

30.verse: Then God said to Hezekiah, “Here is the proof that I am the one who is delivering this city from the king of Assyria: This year he will abandon his siege. Although it is too late now to plant your crops, and you will have only volunteer grain this fall, still it will give you enough seed for a small harvest next year, and two years from now you will be living in luxury again.*

31.verse: And you who are left in Judah will take root again in your own soil and flourish and multiply.

32.verse: For a remnant shall go out from Jerusalem to repopulate the land; the power of the Lord Almighty will cause all this to come to pass.

33.verse: “As for the king of Assyria, his armies shall not enter Jerusalem, nor shoot their arrows there, nor march outside its gates, nor build up an earthen bank against its walls.

34.verse: He will return to his own country by the road he came on and will not enter this city, says the Lord.

35.verse: For my own honor I will defend it and in memory of my servant David.”

36.verse: That night the Angel of the Lord went out to the camp of the Assyrians and killed 185,000 soldiers; when the living wakened the next morning, all these lay dead before them.

37.verse: Then Sennacherib, king of Assyria, returned to his own country, to Nineveh.

38.verse: And one day while he was worshiping in the temple of Nisroch his god, his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer killed him with their swords; then they escaped into the land of Ararat, and Esar-haddon his son became king.

1.verse: It was just before all this that Hezekiah became deathly sick, and Isaiah the prophet (Amoz’ son) went to visit him and gave him this message from the Lord: “Set your affairs in order, for you are going to die; you will not recover from this illness.”

2.verse: When Hezekiah heard this, he turned his face to the wall and prayed:

3.verse: “O Lord, don’t you remember how true I’ve been to you and how I’ve always tried to obey you in everything you said?” Then he broke down with great sobs.

4.verse: So the Lord sent another message to Isaiah:

5.verse: “Go and tell Hezekiah that the Lord God of your forefather David hears you praying and sees your tears and will let you live fifteen more years.

6.verse: He will deliver you and this city from the king of Assyria. I will defend you, says the Lord,

7.verse: and here is my guarantee:

8.verse: I will send the sun backwards ten degrees as measured on Ahaz’s sundial!” So the sun retraced ten degrees that it had gone down!

9.verse: When King Hezekiah was well again, he wrote this poem about his experience:

10.verse: “My life is but half done and I must leave it all. I am robbed of my normal years, and now I must enter the gates of Sheol.

11.verse: Never again will I see the Lord in the land of the living. Never again will I see my friends in this world.

12.verse: My life is blown away like a shepherd’s tent; it is cut short as when a weaver stops his working at the loom. In one short day my life hangs by a thread.

13.verse: “All night I moaned; it was like being torn apart by lions.

14.verse: Delirious, I chattered like a swallow and mourned like a dove; my eyes grew weary of looking up for help. ‘O God,’ I cried, ‘I am in trouble—help me.’

15.verse: But what can I say? For he himself has sent this sickness. All my sleep has fled because of my soul’s bitterness.

16.verse: O Lord, your discipline is good and leads to life and health. Oh, heal me and make me live!

17.verse: “Yes, now I see it all—it was good for me to undergo this bitterness, for you have lovingly delivered me from death; you have forgiven all my sins.

18.verse: For dead men cannot praise you. They cannot be filled with hope and joy.

19.verse: The living, only the living, can praise you as I do today. One generation makes known your faithfulness to the next.

20.verse: Think of it! The Lord healed me! Every day of my life from now on I will sing my songs of praise in the Temple, accompanied by the orchestra.”

21.verse: (For Isaiah had told Hezekiah’s servants, “Make an ointment of figs and spread it over the boil, and he will get well again.”

22.verse: And then Hezekiah had asked, “What sign will the Lord give me to prove that he will heal me?”)

1.verse: Soon afterwards, the king of Babylon (Merodach-baladan, the son of Baladan) sent Hezekiah a present and his best wishes, for he had heard that Hezekiah had been very sick and now was well again.

2.verse: Hezekiah appreciated this and took the envoys from Babylon on a tour of the palace, showing them his treasure-house full of silver, gold, spices, and perfumes. He took them into his jewel rooms, too, and opened to them all his treasures—everything.

3.verse: Then Isaiah the prophet came to the king and said, “What did they say? Where are they from?” “From far away in Babylon,” Hezekiah replied.

4.verse: “How much have they seen?” asked Isaiah. And Hezekiah replied, “I showed them everything I own, all my priceless treasures.”

5.verse: Then Isaiah said to him, “Listen to this message from the Lord Almighty:

6.verse: “The time is coming when everything you have—all the treasures stored up by your fathers—will be carried off to Babylon. Nothing will be left.

7.verse: And some of your own sons will become slaves, yes, eunuchs, in the palace of the king of Babylon.”

8.verse: “All right,” Hezekiah replied. “Whatever the Lord says is good. At least there will be peace during my lifetime!”

1.verse: “Comfort, yes, comfort my people,” says your God.

2.verse: “Speak tenderly to Jerusalem and tell her that her sad days are gone. Her sins are pardoned, and I have punished her in full for all her sins.”

3.verse: Listen! I hear the voice of someone shouting, “Make a road for the Lord through the wilderness; make him a straight, smooth road through the desert.

4.verse: Fill the valleys; level the hills; straighten out the crooked paths, and smooth off the rough spots in the road.

5.verse: The glory of the Lord will be seen by all mankind together.” The Lord has spoken—it shall be.

6.verse: The voice says, “Shout!” “What shall I shout?” I asked. “Shout that man is like the grass that dies away, and all his beauty fades like dying flowers.

7.verse: The grass withers, the flower fades beneath the breath of God. And so it is with fragile man.

8.verse: The grass withers, the flowers fade, but the word of our God shall stand forever.”

9.verse: O crier of good news, shout to Jerusalem from the mountaintops! Shout louder—don’t be afraid—tell the cities of Judah, “Your God is coming!”

10.verse: Yes, the Lord God is coming with mighty power; he will rule with awesome strength. See, his reward is with him, to each as he has done.

11.verse: He will feed his flock like a shepherd; he will carry the lambs in his arms and gently lead the ewes with young.

12.verse: Who else has held the oceans in his hands and measured off the heavens with his ruler? Who else knows the weight of all the earth and weighs the mountains and the hills?

13.verse: Who can advise the Spirit of the Lord or be his teacher or give him counsel?

14.verse: Has he ever needed anyone’s advice? Did he need instruction as to what is right and best?

15.verse: No, for all the peoples of the world are nothing in comparison with him—they are but a drop in the bucket, dust on the scales. He picks up the islands as though they had no weight at all.

16.verse: All of Lebanon’s forests do not contain sufficient fuel to consume a sacrifice large enough to honor him, nor are all its animals enough to offer to our God.

17.verse: All the nations are as nothing to him; in his eyes they are less than nothing—mere emptiness and froth.

18.verse: How can we describe God? With what can we compare him?

19.verse: With an idol? An idol made from a mold, overlaid with gold, and with silver chains around its neck?

20.verse: The man too poor to buy expensive gods like that will find a tree free from rot and hire a man to carve a face on it, and that’s his god—a god that cannot even move!

21.verse: Are you so ignorant? Are you so deaf to the words of God—the words he gave before the world began? Have you never heard nor understood?

22.verse: It is God who sits above the circle of the earth. (The people below must seem to him like grasshoppers!) He is the one who stretches out the heavens like a curtain and makes his tent from them.

23.verse: He dooms the great men of the world and brings them all to naught.

24.verse: They hardly get started, barely take root, when he blows on them and their work withers, and the wind carries them off like straw.

25.verse: “With whom will you compare me? Who is my equal?” asks the Holy One.

26.verse: Look up into the heavens! Who created all these stars? As a shepherd leads his sheep, calling each by its pet name, and counts them to see that none are lost or strayed, so God does with stars and planets!

27.verse: O Jacob, O Israel, how can you say that the Lord doesn’t see your troubles and isn’t being fair?

28.verse: Don’t you yet understand? Don’t you know by now that the everlasting God, the Creator of the farthest parts of the earth, never grows faint or weary? No one can fathom the depths of his understanding.

29.verse: He gives power to the tired and worn out, and strength to the weak.

30.verse: Even the youths shall be exhausted, and the young men will all give up.

31.verse: But they that wait upon the Lord shall renew their strength. They shall mount up with wings like eagles; they shall run and not be weary; they shall walk and not faint.

1.verse: Listen in silence before me, O lands beyond the sea. Bring your strongest arguments. Come now and speak. The court is ready for your case.

2.verse: Who has stirred up this one from the east, whom victory meets at every step? Who, indeed, but the Lord? God has given him victory over many nations and permitted him to trample kings underfoot and to put entire armies to the sword.

3.verse: He chases them away and goes on safely, though the paths he treads are new.

4.verse: Who has done such mighty deeds, directing the affairs of generations of mankind as they march by? It is I, the Lord, the First and Last; I alone am he.

5.verse: The lands beyond the sea watch in fear and wait for word of Cyrus’s new campaigns. Remote lands tremble and mobilize for war.

6.verse: The craftsmen encourage each other as they rush to make new idols to protect them. The carver hurries the goldsmith, and the molder helps at the anvil. “Good,” they say. “It’s coming along fine. Now we can solder on the arms.” Carefully they join the parts together and then fasten the thing in place so it won’t fall over!

7.verse: The craftsmen encourage each other as they rush to make new idols to protect them. The carver hurries the goldsmith, and the molder helps at the anvil. “Good,” they say. “It’s coming along fine. Now we can solder on the arms.” Carefully they join the parts together and then fasten the thing in place so it won’t fall over!

8.verse: But as for you, O Israel, you are mine, my chosen ones; for you are Abraham’s family, and he was my friend.

9.verse: I have called you back from the ends of the earth and said that you must serve but me alone, for I have chosen you and will not throw you away.

10.verse: Fear not, for I am with you. Do not be dismayed. I am your God. I will strengthen you; I will help you; I will uphold you with my victorious right hand.

11.verse: See, all your angry enemies lie confused and shattered. Anyone opposing you will die.

12.verse: You will look for them in vain—they will all be gone.

13.verse: I am holding you by your right hand—I, the Lord your God—and I say to you, Don’t be afraid; I am here to help you.

14.verse: Despised though you are, fear not, O Israel; for I will help you. I am the Lord, your Redeemer; I am the Holy One of Israel.

15.verse: You shall be a new and sharp-toothed threshing instrument to tear all enemies apart, making chaff of mountains.

16.verse: You shall toss them in the air; the wind shall blow them all away; whirlwinds shall scatter them. And the joy of the Lord shall fill you full; you shall glory in the God of Israel.

17.verse: When the poor and needy seek water and there is none, and their tongues are parched from thirst, then I will answer when they cry to me. I, Israel’s God, will never forsake them.

18.verse: I will open up rivers for them on high plateaus! I will give them fountains of water in the valleys! In the deserts will be pools of water, and rivers fed by springs shall flow across the dry, parched ground.

19.verse: I will plant trees—cedars, myrtle, olive trees, cypress, fir, and pine—on barren land.

20.verse: Everyone will see this miracle and understand that it is God who did it, Israel’s Holy One.

21.verse: Can your idols make such claims as these? Let them come and show what they can do, says God, the King of Israel.

22.verse: Let them try to tell us what occurred in years gone by or what the future holds.

23.verse: Yes, that’s it! If you are gods, tell what will happen in the days ahead! Or do some mighty miracle that makes us stare, amazed.

24.verse: But no! You are less than nothing and can do nothing at all. Anyone who chooses you needs to have his head examined!

25.verse: But I have stirred up Cyrus from the north and east; he will come against the nations and call on my name, and I will give him victory over kings and princes. He will tread them as a potter tramples clay.

26.verse: Who but I have told you this would happen? Who else predicted this, making you admit that he was right? No one else! None other said one word!

27.verse: I was the first to tell Jerusalem, “Look! Look! Help is on the way!”

28.verse: Not one of your idols told you this. Not one gave any answer when I asked.

29.verse: See, they are all foolish, worthless things; your idols are all as empty as the wind.

1.verse: See my servant, whom I uphold; my Chosen One in whom I delight. I have put my Spirit upon him; he will reveal justice to the nations of the world.

2.verse: He will be gentle—he will not shout nor quarrel in the streets.

3.verse: He will not break the bruised reed, nor quench the dimly burning flame. He will encourage the fainthearted, those tempted to despair. He will see full justice given to all who have been wronged.

4.verse: He won’t be satisfied until truth and righteousness prevail throughout the earth, nor until even distant lands beyond the seas have put their trust in him.

5.verse: The Lord God who created the heavens and stretched them out, who created the earth and everything in it, who gives life and breath and spirit to everyone in all the world, he is the one who says to his Servant, the Messiah:

6.verse: “I the Lord have called you to demonstrate my righteousness. I will guard and support you, for I have given you to my people as the personal confirmation of my covenant with them. You shall also be a light to guide the nations unto me.

7.verse: You will open the eyes of the blind and release those who sit in prison darkness and despair.

8.verse: I am the Lord! That is my name, and I will not give my glory to anyone else; I will not share my praise with carved idols.

9.verse: Everything I prophesied came true, and now I will prophesy again. I will tell you the future before it happens.”

10.verse: Sing a new song to the Lord; sing his praises, all you who live in earth’s remotest corners! Sing, O sea! Sing, all you who live in distant lands beyond the sea!

11.verse: Join in the chorus, you desert cities—Kedar and Sela! And you, too, dwellers in the mountaintops.

12.verse: Let the western coastlands glorify the Lord and sing his mighty power.

13.verse: The Lord will be a mighty warrior, full of fury toward his foes. He will give a great shout and prevail.

14.verse: Long has he been silent; he has restrained himself. But now he will give full vent to his wrath; he will groan and cry like a woman delivering her child.

15.verse: He will level the mountains and hills and blight their greenery. He will dry up the rivers and pools.

16.verse: He will bring blind Israel along a path they have not seen before. He will make the darkness bright before them and smooth and straighten out the road ahead. He will not forsake them.

17.verse: But those who trust in idols and call them gods will be greatly disappointed; they will be turned away.

18.verse: Oh, how blind and deaf you are toward God! Why won’t you listen? Why won’t you see?

19.verse: Who in all the world is as blind as my own people, who are designed to be my messengers of truth? Who is so blind as my “dedicated one,” the “servant of the Lord”?

20.verse: You see and understand what is right but won’t heed nor do it; you hear, but you won’t listen.

21.verse: The Lord has magnified his law and made it truly glorious. Through it he had planned to show the world that he is righteous.

22.verse: But what a sight his people are—these who were to demonstrate to all the world the glory of his law; for they are robbed, enslaved, imprisoned, trapped, fair game for all, with no one to protect them.

23.verse: Won’t even one of you apply these lessons from the past and see the ruin that awaits you up ahead?

24.verse: Who let Israel be robbed and hurt? Did not the Lord? It is the Lord they sinned against, for they would not go where he sent them nor listen to his laws.

25.verse: That is why God poured out such fury and wrath on his people and destroyed them in battle. Yet, though set on fire and burned, they will not understand the reason why—that it is God, wanting them to repent.

1.verse: But now the Lord who created you, O Israel, says: Don’t be afraid, for I have ransomed you; I have called you by name; you are mine.

2.verse: When you go through deep waters and great trouble, I will be with you. When you go through rivers of difficulty, you will not drown! When you walk through the fire of oppression, you will not be burned up—the flames will not consume you.

3.verse: For I am the Lord your God, your Savior, the Holy One of Israel. I gave Egypt and Ethiopia and Seba to Cyrus in exchange for your freedom, as your ransom.

4.verse: Others died that you might live; I traded their lives for yours because you are precious to me and honored, and I love you.

5.verse: Don’t be afraid, for I am with you. I will gather you from east and west,

6.verse: from north and south. I will bring my sons and daughters back to Israel from the farthest corners of the earth.

7.verse: All who claim me as their God will come, for I have made them for my glory; I created them.

8.verse: Bring them back to me—blind as they are and deaf when I call (although they see and hear!).

9.verse: Gather the nations together! Which of all their idols ever has foretold such things? Which can predict a single day ahead? Where are the witnesses of anything they said? If there are no witnesses, then they must confess that only God can prophesy.

10.verse: But I have witnesses, O Israel, says the Lord! You are my witnesses and my servants, chosen to know and to believe me and to understand that I alone am God. There is no other God; there never was and never will be.

11.verse: I am the Lord, and there is no other Savior.

12.verse: Whenever you have thrown away your idols, I have shown you my power. With one word I have saved you. You have seen me do it; you are my witnesses that it is true.

13.verse: From eternity to eternity I am God. No one can oppose what I do.

14.verse: The Lord, your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel, says: For your sakes I will send an invading army against Babylon that will walk in, almost unscathed. The boasts of the Babylonians will turn to cries of fear.

15.verse: I am the Lord, your Holy One, Israel’s Creator and King.

16.verse: I am the Lord, who opened a way through the waters, making a path right through the sea.

17.verse: I called forth the mighty army of Egypt with all its chariots and horses, to lie beneath the waves, dead, their lives snuffed out like candlewicks.

18.verse: But forget all that—it is nothing compared to what I’m going to do!

19.verse: For I’m going to do a brand-new thing. See, I have already begun! Don’t you see it? I will make a road through the wilderness of the world for my people to go home, and create rivers for them in the desert!

20.verse: The wild animals in the fields will thank me, the jackals and ostriches too, for giving them water in the wilderness, yes, springs in the desert, so that my people, my chosen ones, can be refreshed.

21.verse: I have made Israel for myself, and these my people will some day honor me before the world.

22.verse: But O my people, you won’t ask my help; you have grown tired of me!

23.verse: You have not brought me the lambs for burnt offerings; you have not honored me with sacrifices. Yet my requests for offerings and incense have been very few! I have not treated you as slaves.

24.verse: You have brought me no sweet-smelling incense nor pleased me with the sacrificial fat. No, you have presented me only with sins and wearied me with all your faults.

25.verse: I, yes, I alone am he who blots away your sins for my own sake and will never think of them again.

26.verse: Oh, remind me of this promise of forgiveness, for we must talk about your sins. Plead your case for my forgiving you.

27.verse: From the very first your ancestors sinned against me—all your forebears transgressed my law.

28.verse: That is why I have deposed your priests and destroyed Israel, leaving her to shame.

1.verse: Listen to me, O my servant Israel, O my chosen ones:

2.verse: The Lord who made you, who will help you, says: O servant of mine, don’t be afraid. O Jerusalem, my chosen ones, don’t be afraid.

3.verse: For I will give you abundant water for your thirst and for your parched fields. And I will pour out my Spirit and my blessings on your children.

4.verse: They shall thrive like watered grass, like willows on a riverbank.

5.verse: “I am the Lord’s,” they’ll proudly say, or, “I am a Jew,” and tattoo upon their hands the name of God or the honored name of Israel.

6.verse: The Lord, the King of Israel, says—yes, it is Israel’s Redeemer, the Lord Almighty, who says it—I am the First and Last; there is no other God.

7.verse: Who else can tell you what is going to happen in the days ahead? Let them tell you if they can and prove their power. Let them do as I have done since ancient times.

8.verse: Don’t, don’t be afraid. Haven’t I proclaimed from ages past that I would save you? You are my witnesses—is there any other God? No! None that I know about! There is no other Rock!

9.verse: What fools they are who manufacture idols for their gods. Their hopes remain unanswered. They themselves are witnesses that this is so, for their idols neither see nor know. No wonder those who worship them are so ashamed.

10.verse: Who but a fool would make his own god—an idol that can help him not one whit!

11.verse: All that worship these will stand before the Lord in shame, along with all these carpenters—mere men—who claim that they have made a god. Together they will stand in terror.

12.verse: The metalsmith stands at his forge to make an ax, pounding on it with all his might. He grows hungry and thirsty, weak and faint.

13.verse: Then the wood-carver takes the ax and uses it to make an idol. He measures and marks out a block of wood and carves the figure of a man. Now he has a wonderful idol that can’t so much as move from where it is placed.

14.verse: He cuts down cedars, he selects the cypress and the oak, he plants the ash in the forest to be nourished by the rain.

15.verse: And after his care, he uses part of the wood to make a fire to warm himself and bake his bread, and then—he really does—he takes the rest of it and makes himself a god—a god for men to worship! An idol to fall down before and praise!

16.verse: Part of the tree he burns to roast his meat and to keep him warm and fed and well content,

17.verse: and with what’s left he makes his god: a carved idol! He falls down before it and worships it and prays to it. “Deliver me,” he says. “You are my god!”

18.verse: Such stupidity and ignorance! God has shut their eyes so that they cannot see and closed their minds from understanding.

19.verse: The man never stops to think or figure out, “Why, it’s just a block of wood! I’ve burned it for heat and used it to bake my bread and roast my meat. How can the rest of it be a god? Should I fall down before a chunk of wood?”

20.verse: The poor, deluded fool feeds on ashes; he is trusting what can never give him any help at all. Yet he cannot bring himself to ask, “Is this thing, this idol that I’m holding in my hand, a lie?”

21.verse: Pay attention, Israel, for you are my servant; I made you, and I will not forget to help you.

22.verse: I’ve blotted out your sins; they are gone like morning mist at noon! Oh, return to me, for I have paid the price to set you free.

23.verse: Sing, O heavens, for the Lord has done this wondrous thing. Shout, O earth; break forth into song, O mountains and forests, yes, and every tree; for the Lord redeemed Jacob and is glorified in Israel!

24.verse: The Lord, your Redeemer who made you, says: All things were made by me; I alone stretched out the heavens. By myself I made the earth and everything in it.

25.verse: I am the one who shows what liars all false prophets are, by causing something else to happen than the things they say. I make wise men give opposite advice to what they should and make them into fools.

26.verse: But what my prophets say, I do; when they say Jerusalem will be delivered and the cities of Judah lived in once again—it shall be done!

27.verse: When I speak to the rivers and say, “Be dry!” they shall be dry.

28.verse: When I say of Cyrus, “He is my shepherd,” he will certainly do as I say; and Jerusalem will be rebuilt and the Temple restored, for I have spoken it.

1.verse: This is Jehovah’s message to Cyrus, God’s anointed, whom he has chosen to conquer many lands. God shall empower his right hand, and he shall crush the strength of mighty kings. God shall open the gates of Babylon to him; the gates shall not be shut against him anymore.

2.verse: I will go before you, Cyrus, and level the mountains and smash down the city gates of brass and iron bars.

3.verse: And I will give you treasures hidden in the darkness, secret riches; and you will know that I am doing this—I, the Lord, the God of Israel, the one who calls you by your name.

4.verse: And why have I named you for this work? For the sake of Jacob, my servant—Israel, my chosen. I called you by name when you didn’t know me.

5.verse: I am Jehovah; there is no other God. I will strengthen you and send you out to victory even though you don’t know me,

6.verse: and all the world from east to west will know there is no other God. I am Jehovah and there is no one else. I alone am God.

7.verse: I form the light and make the dark. I send good times and bad. I, Jehovah, am he who does these things.

8.verse: Open up, O heavens. Let the skies pour out their righteousness. Let salvation and righteousness sprout up together from the earth. I, Jehovah, created them.

9.verse: Woe to the man who fights with his Creator. Does the pot argue with its maker? Does the clay dispute with him who forms it, saying, “Stop, you’re doing it wrong!” or the pot exclaim, “How clumsy can you be!”?

10.verse: Woe to the baby just being born who squalls to his father and mother, “Why have you produced me? Can’t you do anything right at all?”

11.verse: Jehovah, the Holy One of Israel, Israel’s Creator, says: What right have you to question what I do? Who are you to command me concerning the work of my hands?

12.verse: I have made the earth and created man upon it. With my hands I have stretched out the heavens and commanded all the vast myriads of stars.

13.verse: I have raised up Cyrus to fulfill my righteous purpose, and I will direct all his paths. He shall restore my city and free my captive people—and not for a reward!

14.verse: Jehovah says: The Egyptians, Ethiopians, and Sabeans shall be subject to you. They shall come to you with all their merchandise, and it shall all be yours. They shall follow you as prisoners in chains and fall down on their knees before you and say, “The only God there is, is your God!”

15.verse: Truly, O God of Israel, Savior, you work in strange, mysterious ways.

16.verse: All who worship idols shall be disappointed and ashamed.

17.verse: But Israel shall be saved by Jehovah with eternal salvation; they shall never be disappointed in their God through all eternity.

18.verse: For Jehovah created the heavens and earth and put everything in place, and he made the world to be lived in, not to be an empty chaos. I am Jehovah, he says, and there is no other!

19.verse: I publicly proclaim bold promises; I do not whisper obscurities in some dark corner so that no one can know what I mean. And I didn’t tell Israel to ask me for what I didn’t plan to give! No, for I, Jehovah, speak only truth and righteousness.

20.verse: Gather together and come, you nations that escape from Cyrus’s hand. What fools they are who carry around the wooden idols and pray to gods that cannot save!

21.verse: Consult together, argue your case and state your proofs that idol worship pays! Who but God has said that these things concerning Cyrus would come true? What idol ever told you they would happen? For there is no other God but me—a just God and a Savior—no, not one!

22.verse: Let all the world look to me for salvation! For I am God; there is no other.

23.verse: I have sworn by myself, and I will never go back on my word, for it is true—that every knee in all the world shall bow to me, and every tongue shall swear allegiance to my name.

24.verse: “In Jehovah is all my righteousness and strength,” the people shall declare. And all who were angry with him shall come to him and be ashamed.

25.verse: In Jehovah all the generations of Israel shall be justified, triumphant.

1.verse: The idols of Babylon, Bel and Nebo, are being hauled away on ox carts! But look! The beasts are stumbling! The cart is turning over! The gods are falling out onto the ground! Is that the best that they can do? If they cannot even save themselves from such a fall, how can they save their worshipers from Cyrus?

2.verse: The idols of Babylon, Bel and Nebo, are being hauled away on ox carts! But look! The beasts are stumbling! The cart is turning over! The gods are falling out onto the ground! Is that the best that they can do? If they cannot even save themselves from such a fall, how can they save their worshipers from Cyrus?

3.verse: “Listen to me, all Israel who are left; I have created you and cared for you since you were born.

4.verse: I will be your God through all your lifetime, yes, even when your hair is white with age. I made you and I will care for you. I will carry you along and be your Savior.

5.verse: “With what in all of heaven and earth do I compare? Whom can you find who equals me?

6.verse: Will you compare me with an idol made lavishly with silver and with gold? They hire a goldsmith to take your wealth and make a god from it! Then they fall down and worship it!

7.verse: They carry it around on their shoulders, and when they set it down, it stays there, for it cannot move! And when someone prays to it, there is no answer, for it cannot get him out of his trouble.

8.verse: “Don’t forget this, O guilty ones.

9.verse: And don’t forget the many times I clearly told you what was going to happen in the future. For I am God—I only—and there is no other like me

10.verse: who can tell you what is going to happen. All I say will come to pass, for I do whatever I wish.

11.verse: I will call that swift bird of prey from the east—that man Cyrus from far away. And he will come and do my bidding. I have said I would do it and I will.

12.verse: Listen to me, you stubborn, evil men!

13.verse: For I am offering you my deliverance; not in the distant future, but right now! I am ready to save you, and I will restore Jerusalem and Israel, who is my glory.

1.verse: “O Babylon, the unconquered, come sit in the dust; for your days of glory, pomp, and honor are ended. O daughter of Chaldea, never again will you be the lovely princess, tender and delicate.

2.verse: Take heavy millstones and grind the corn; remove your veil; strip off your robe; expose yourself to public view.

3.verse: You shall be in nakedness and shame. I will take vengeance upon you and will not repent.”

4.verse: So speaks our Redeemer, who will save Israel from Babylon’s mighty power; the Lord Almighty is his name, the Holy One of Israel.

5.verse: Sit in darkness and silence, O Babylon; never again will you be called “The Queen of Kingdoms.”

6.verse: For I was angry with my people Israel and began to punish them a little by letting them fall into your hands, O Babylon. But you showed them no mercy. You have made even the old folks carry heavy burdens.

7.verse: You thought your reign would never end, Queen Kingdom of the world. You didn’t care a whit about my people or think about the fate of those who do them harm.

8.verse: O pleasure-mad kingdom, living at ease, bragging as the greatest in the world—listen to the sentence of my court upon your sins. You say, “I alone am God! I’ll never be a widow; I’ll never lose my children.”

9.verse: Well, those two things shall come upon you in one moment, in full measure in one day: widowhood and the loss of your children, despite all your witchcraft and magic.

10.verse: You felt secure in all your wickedness. “No one sees me,” you said. Your “wisdom” and “knowledge” have caused you to turn away from me and claim that you yourself are Jehovah.

11.verse: That is why disaster shall overtake you suddenly—so suddenly that you won’t know where it comes from. And there will be no atonement then to cleanse away your sins.

12.verse: Call out the demon hordes you’ve worshiped all these years. Call on them to help you strike deep terror into many hearts again.

13.verse: You have advisors by the ton—your astrologers and stargazers, who try to tell you what the future holds.

14.verse: But they are as useless as dried grass burning in the fire. They cannot even deliver themselves! You’ll get no help from them at all. Theirs is no fire to sit beside to make you warm!

15.verse: And all your friends of childhood days shall slip away and disappear, unable to help.

1.verse: Hear me, my people: you swear allegiance to the Lord without meaning a word of it when you boast of living in the Holy City and brag about depending on the God of Israel.

2.verse: Hear me, my people: you swear allegiance to the Lord without meaning a word of it when you boast of living in the Holy City and brag about depending on the God of Israel.

3.verse: Time and again I told you what was going to happen in the future. My words were scarcely spoken when suddenly I did just what I said.

4.verse: I knew how hard and obstinate you are. Your necks are as unbending as iron; you are as hardheaded as brass.

5.verse: That is why I told you ahead of time what I was going to do, so that you could never say, “My idol did it; my carved image commanded it to happen!”

6.verse: You have heard my predictions and seen them fulfilled, but you refuse to agree it is so. Now I will tell you new things I haven’t mentioned before, secrets you haven’t heard.

7.verse: Then you can’t say, “We knew that all the time!”

8.verse: Yes, I’ll tell you things entirely new, for I know so well what traitors you are, rebels from earliest childhood, rotten through and through.

9.verse: Yet for my own sake and for the honor of my name I will hold back my anger and not wipe you out.

10.verse: I refined you in the furnace of affliction, but found no silver there. You are worthless, with nothing good in you at all.

11.verse: Yet for my own sake—yes, for my own sake—I will save you from my anger and not destroy you lest the heathen say their gods have conquered me. I will not let them have my glory.

12.verse: Listen to me, my people, my chosen ones! I alone am God. I am the First; I am the Last.

13.verse: It was my hand that laid the foundations of the earth; the palm of my right hand spread out the heavens above; I spoke and they came into being.

14.verse: Come, all of you, and listen. Among all your idols, which one has ever told you this: “The Lord loves Cyrus. He will use him to put an end to the empire of Babylonia. He will utterly rout the armies of the Chaldeans”?

15.verse: But I am saying it. I have called Cyrus; I have sent him on this errand, and I will prosper him.

16.verse: Come closer and listen. I have always told you plainly what would happen, so that you could clearly understand. And now the Lord God and his Spirit have sent me (with this message):

17.verse: The Lord, your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel, says: I am the Lord your God, who punishes you for your own good and leads you along the paths that you should follow.

18.verse: Oh, that you had listened to my laws! Then you would have had peace flowing like a gentle river, and great waves of righteousness.

19.verse: Then you would have become as numerous as the sands along the seashores of the world, too many to count, and there would have been no need for your destruction.

20.verse: Yet even now, be free from your captivity! Leave Babylon, singing as you go; shout to the ends of the earth that the Lord has redeemed his servants, the Jews.

21.verse: They were not thirsty when he led them through the deserts; he divided the rock, and water gushed out for them to drink.

22.verse: But there is no peace, says the Lord, for the wicked.

1.verse: Listen to me, all of you in far-off lands: The Lord called me before my birth. From within the womb he called me by my name.

2.verse: God will make my words of judgment sharp as swords. He has hidden me in the shadow of his hand; I am like a sharp arrow in his quiver.

3.verse: He said to me: “You are my servant, a prince of power with God, and you shall bring me glory.”

4.verse: I replied, “But my work for them seems all in vain; I have spent my strength for them without response. Yet I leave it all with God for my reward.”

5.verse: “And now,” said the Lord—the Lord who formed me from my mother’s womb to serve him who commissioned me to restore to him his people Israel, who has given me the strength to perform this task and honored me for doing it!—

6.verse: “you shall do more than restore Israel to me. I will make you a Light to the nations of the world to bring my salvation to them too.”

7.verse: The Lord, the Redeemer and Holy One of Israel, says to the One who is despised, rejected by mankind, and kept beneath the heel of the world’s rulers: “Kings shall stand at attention when you pass by; princes shall bow low because the Lord has chosen you; he, the faithful Lord, the Holy One of Israel, chooses you.”

8.verse: The Lord says, “Your request has come at a favorable time. I will keep you from harm and give you as a token and pledge to Israel, proof that I will reestablish the land of Israel and reassign it to its own people again. Through you I am saying to the prisoners of darkness, ‘Come out! I am giving you your freedom!’ They will be my sheep, grazing in green pastures and on the grassy hills.

9.verse: The Lord says, “Your request has come at a favorable time. I will keep you from harm and give you as a token and pledge to Israel, proof that I will reestablish the land of Israel and reassign it to its own people again. Through you I am saying to the prisoners of darkness, ‘Come out! I am giving you your freedom!’ They will be my sheep, grazing in green pastures and on the grassy hills.

10.verse: They shall neither hunger nor thirst; the searing sun and scorching desert winds will not reach them anymore. For the Lord in his mercy will lead them beside the cool waters.

11.verse: And I will make my mountains into level paths for them; the highways shall be raised above the valleys.

12.verse: See, my people shall return from far away, from north and west and south.”

13.verse: Sing for joy, O heavens; shout, O earth. Break forth with song, O mountains, for the Lord has comforted his people and will have compassion upon them in their sorrow.

14.verse: Yet they say, “My Lord deserted us; he has forgotten us.”

15.verse: “Never! Can a mother forget her little child and not have love for her own son? Yet even if that should be, I will not forget you.

16.verse: See, I have tattooed your name upon my palm, and ever before me is a picture of Jerusalem’s walls in ruins.

17.verse: Soon your rebuilders shall come and chase away all those destroying you.

18.verse: Look and see, for the Lord has vowed that all your enemies shall come and be your slaves. They will be as jewels to display, as bridal ornaments.

19.verse: “Even the most desolate parts of your abandoned land shall soon be crowded with your people, and your enemies who enslaved you shall be far away.

20.verse: The generations born in exile shall return and say, ‘We need more room! It’s crowded here!’

21.verse: Then you will think to yourself, ‘Who has given me all these? For most of my children were killed, and the rest were carried away into exile, leaving me here alone. Who bore these? Who raised them for me?’”

22.verse: The Lord God says, “See, I will give a signal to the Gentiles, and they shall carry your little sons back to you in their arms, and your daughters on their shoulders.

23.verse: Kings and queens shall serve you; they shall care for all your needs. They shall bow to the earth before you and lick the dust from off your feet; then you shall know I am the Lord. Those who wait for me shall never be ashamed.”

24.verse: Who can snatch the prey from the hands of a mighty man? Who can demand that a tyrant let his captives go?

25.verse: But the Lord says, “Even the captives of the most mighty and most terrible shall all be freed; for I will fight those who fight you, and I will save your children.

26.verse: I will feed your enemies with their own flesh, and they shall be drunk with rivers of their own blood. All the world shall know that I, the Lord, am your Savior and Redeemer, the Mighty One of Israel.”

1.verse: The Lord asks, Did I sell you to my creditors? Is that why you aren’t here? Is your mother gone because I divorced her and sent her away? No, you went away as captives because of your sins. And your mother, too, was taken in payment for your sins.

2.verse: Was I too weak to save you? Is that why the house is silent and empty when I come home? Have I no longer power to deliver? No, that is not the reason! For I can rebuke the sea and make it dry! I can turn the rivers into deserts, covered with dying fish.

3.verse: I am the one who sends the darkness out across the skies.

4.verse: The Lord God has given me his words of wisdom so that I may know what I should say to all these weary ones. Morning by morning he wakens me and opens my understanding to his will.

5.verse: The Lord God has spoken to me, and I have listened; I do not rebel nor turn away.

6.verse: I give my back to the whip, and my cheeks to those who pull out the beard. I do not hide from shame—they spit in my face.

7.verse: Because the Lord God helps me, I will not be dismayed; therefore, I have set my face like flint to do his will, and I know that I will triumph.

8.verse: He who gives me justice is near. Who will dare to fight against me now? Where are my enemies? Let them appear!

9.verse: See, the Lord God is for me! Who shall declare me guilty? All my enemies shall be destroyed like old clothes eaten up by moths!

10.verse: Who among you fears the Lord and obeys his Servant? If such men walk in darkness, without one ray of light, let them trust the Lord, let them rely upon their God.

11.verse: But see here, you who live in your own light and warm yourselves from your own fires and not from God’s; you will live among sorrows.

1.verse: Listen to me, all who hope for deliverance, who seek the Lord! Consider the quarry from which you were mined, the rock from which you were cut! Yes, think about your ancestors Abraham and Sarah, from whom you came. You worry at being so small and few, but Abraham was only one when I called him. But when I blessed him, he became a great nation.

2.verse: Listen to me, all who hope for deliverance, who seek the Lord! Consider the quarry from which you were mined, the rock from which you were cut! Yes, think about your ancestors Abraham and Sarah, from whom you came. You worry at being so small and few, but Abraham was only one when I called him. But when I blessed him, he became a great nation.

3.verse: And the Lord will bless Israel again, and make her deserts blossom; her barren wilderness will become as beautiful as the Garden of Eden. Joy and gladness will be found there, thanksgiving and lovely songs.

4.verse: Listen to me, my people; listen, O Israel, for I will see that right prevails.

5.verse: My mercy and justice are coming soon; your salvation is on the way. I will rule the nations; they shall wait for me and long for me to come.

6.verse: Look high in the skies and watch the earth beneath, for the skies shall disappear like smoke, the earth shall wear out like a garment, and the people of the earth shall die like flies. But my salvation lasts forever; my righteous rule will never die nor end.

7.verse: Listen to me, you who know the right from wrong and cherish my laws in your hearts: don’t be afraid of people’s scorn or their slanderous talk.

8.verse: For the moth shall destroy them like garments; the worm shall eat them like wool; but my justice and mercy shall last forever, and my salvation from generation to generation.

9.verse: Awake, O Lord! Rise up and robe yourself with strength. Rouse yourself as in the days of old when you slew Egypt, the dragon of the Nile.

10.verse: Are you not the same today, the mighty God who dried up the sea, making a path right through it for your ransomed ones?
